And you will still observe deceit among them, except a few of them. But pardon them and overlook [their misdeeds]. Indeed, Allah loves the doers of good. (al-Ma'idah/5: 13)

Allah commands the believers to fight the People of the Book because they show hostility and threaten the security of Muslims, both in religious and social life. If they accept Islam as a replacement for their religion, then they have returned to the true religion, and if they submit, no longer disturb and threaten the lives of Muslims, then they should pay the *jizyah* (except for the poor and the priests) as a sign that they are in a low position. The obligation of all Muslims is to guarantee their security, defend them, give them freedom, especially in carrying out worship according to their religion, and treat them fairly in social life as Muslims themselves are treated. By paying the *jizyah*, they are called *ahli zimmah* or *kafir zimmi*.
text.30:
This verse explains the erroneous beliefs of the People of the Book, both Jews and Christians. They believe that Allah has a son; the Jews adhere to the belief that "Uzair is the son of Allah." This belief is completely contrary to the true understanding of faith in Allah, because true faith is that Allah is One, singular, without a father and without association with anything or anyone. He is Most Perfect, Most Powerful, and there is nothing similar or equal to Him.

Uzair was a Jewish priest, a resident of Babylon, who lived around 457 BC. He was a distinguished author, founder of a large association, and diligent in collecting manuscripts of the Holy Scriptures from various regions. He was the one who introduced Chaldean or Aramaic letters as replacements for ancient Hebrew letters. He also wrote about the movements of the sun and reorganized valuable books that had been scattered. During his lifetime, he was considered a period of fertility for the Jewish religion, because he was the leading poet of the Torah law, reviving that law after it had been forgotten for so long. Therefore, the Jews considered him a saint who was closer to Allah, and some of them, who were fanatical, considered and called him "the son of Allah." Although only some of the Jews believed this, it can be considered that this belief was their entire belief because the wrong statement was not refuted or denied by other groups. Allah says:

And fear a trial which will not strike those who have wronged among you exclusively. (al-Anfal/8: 25)

Similarly, the Christians regarding Isa Al-Masih. They believe that Isa is the son of Allah. This belief is also very contrary to faith in Allah swt. Even though initially the words "Isa is the son of Allah" were only the words of their ancestors who considered Isa to be a noble person, loved by Allah and honored, and those words did not mean the actual son of Allah. However, gradually, especially when Hindu religious beliefs seeped into the Christians and the two religions stood side by side, shoulder to shoulder, the belief that Isa Al-Masih was truly the son of Allah was planted in their hearts. Then, after some time, a change arose in their beliefs, that the son of Allah and Allah are also the Holy Spirit (Rohulkudus), which later became known as "Father, son and holy spirit," essentially united in Allah.

According to their belief, the three elements, namely: the Son of Allah, Allah and the Holy Spirit, are essentially one. This teaching has become a decree in the Christian religion, three centuries after the death of Isa Al-Masih. Although this belief is opposed by some of them, who are not small in number, the Catholic, Orthodox, and Protestant churches remain steadfast in their stance. In fact, people who do not justify that belief are considered no longer part of the Christians and have apostatized from their religion.

Saying that Isa Al-Masih is the son of Allah and believing that the three holy persons are the essence of God Almighty is not justified by Allah swt and cannot be accepted by sound reason, and not a single religion of the prophets before that adhered to such a belief. Allah swt emphasizes that their words like that do not have the slightest essence of truth and there is not a single argument or real evidence that can strengthen it. In line with this, Allah swt says:

Grave is the word that comes out of their mouths; they speak not except a lie. (al-Kahf/18: 5)

In the books of the New Testament itself, there is no statement stating that Isa Al-Masih is the son of Allah. Indeed, they have strayed far from the true teachings. They imitate the words of previous disbelievers, such as the polytheists of the Arab nation who said that the angels were the daughters of Allah.

History records that the belief "God begets, God incarnates in three elements of one essence" is the belief of the Brahma and Buddha people in India, the beliefs of the Japanese, Persian, Egyptian, Greek, and Roman nations of ancient times. The situation of the Jews and Christians believing that Allah swt begets has never been known by anyone from the Arab nation, nor by the people around them. And only with the revelation of the Qur'an was the confusion of their understanding of the essence of the Prophet Isa, God, and the Holy Spirit known. If there were no verses correcting this misunderstanding, of course that error would not be realized until now. This is one of the miracles of the Qur'an.

Allah swt curses them because they are unwilling to realize and be aware of their errors and deviations. Even though the Messengers of Allah have explained that Allah is One, does not beget and is not begotten, they do not want to return to the creed of monotheism, but instead persist in their erroneous belief, namely considering that Uzair and Isa Al-Masih are the sons of Allah. Even though both are ordinary humans and His servants, like other humans, even though it is acknowledged that both are righteous humans, obedient to Allah and His Messenger, noble and respected, as Allah says:

And they say, "The Most Merciful has taken a son." Exalted is He. Rather, they [i.e., the angels] are honored servants. (al-Anbiya'/21: 26)
text.31:
In this verse, the forms of deviation of the People of the Book, the Jews and the Christians, are explained, each taking and elevating gods besides Allah swt. The Jews made their religious priests as gods who have the right to establish laws to permit and prohibit. Meanwhile, the Christians made their monks as gods who must be obeyed and worshiped. In Islam, the position of religious leaders is no more than an expert who has in-depth knowledge of the intricacies of the Sharia. All opinions and fatwas put forward are only explanations of Allah's laws that must be accompanied and based on clear evidence from Allah's words swt, or the Sunnah of the Prophet. They do not have the slightest right to make Sharia, because Sharia is the right of Allah alone.

According to followers of Christianity, besides Jesus Christ being considered a god to be worshiped, some also worship his mother, Maryam, even though Jesus was a messenger like the previous messengers and Maryam, his mother, was only a pious woman who diligently worshiped, thus receiving the title Maryam Al-Butul, and both of them ate and drank as other humans do. Allah swt says:

"The Messiah, son of Mary, was not but a messenger. [Other] messengers have passed on before him. And his mother was a supporter of truth. They both used to eat food." (al-Ma'idah/5: 75)

Christian, Catholic and Orthodox believers worship the disciples of Jesus and his messengers, as well as the heads and leaders of their religion, who are considered sacred, and make them intermediaries who will convey their worship to Allah. They also consider their priests to have the right to forgive or not forgive according to their wishes, even though no one has the right to forgive sins except Allah swt, as He says:

"And who can forgive sins except Allah?" (Ali-Imran/3: 135)

As for the Jews, they added other laws to the Sharia of their religion. They did not suffice and limit themselves to the laws contained in the Torah as a guide for their lives, but added and included other laws that they heard from their religious leaders before these laws were codified into regulations that must be followed and obeyed by Jewish adherents.

Such are the deviations that have been committed by the People of the Book, even though they were not commanded except to worship the One God, the Lord of all the worlds, namely Allah swt, because there is no God worthy of worship except Him. He is the One God, there is no partner for Him, neither in His essence, His attributes, nor His actions. Glory be to Allah swt from what they associate with Him. If they believe that their leaders have the right to determine a law, it means they have the belief that there is a God who is worshiped besides Allah swt who can inflict disease and heal, give life and death without Allah's permission. All of that arises from the desires of their lusts and their minds, not sourced from divine revelation.
text.32:
This verse explains the evil desires of the People of the Book. They want to eliminate the religion of monotheism, which is the religion brought by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), a religion full of evidence demonstrating the Oneness of Allah (SWT), a religion that sanctifies Him from things that are not befitting of Him. Muslims believe that the teachings of Islam are supreme, as the Prophet (peace be upon him) said:

"Islam is supreme and nothing is superior to it." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

All sorts of efforts and endeavors are made by them, both through subtle means and through harsh means, in the form of violence, persecution, warfare, and so on, to destroy the religion of Allah, which is likened to *nur* or light that illuminates the universe. But Allah does not approve of that evil intention. All their efforts are unsuccessful, while the religion of Islam is expanding day by day to the remote corners, so that the world recognizes its purity, even though not all of humanity has embraced it.

Even though the evidence is sufficient and the realities have clearly shown the truth of the religion of Islam, they still deny it. They work hard with all kinds of efforts and ways, so that the Muslims are willing to leave their religion or embrace their religion.

And the Jews and the Christians will never be pleased with you until you follow their religion. (al-Baqarah/2: 120)

And His saying:

Hatred has already appeared from their mouths, and what their hearts conceal is far worse. (Ali 'Imran/3: 118)
text.33:
This verse explains that as a guarantee of the perfection of religion, a messenger, namely the Prophet Muhammad SAW, was sent and equipped with a holy book, namely the Al-Qur'an, which contains guidance that explains everything and encompasses the contents of previous books. Allah has approved Islam to be the religion followed by all of mankind. Allah SWT says:

"And I have approved for you Islam as religion." (al-Ma'idah/5: 3)

Islam is suitable for all circumstances and places and applies throughout time from when it was prescribed until the end of time. Therefore, it is not surprising that Islam has been welcomed by all of mankind and its numbers have grown rapidly, so that in a short time it has spread to all corners of the world, occupying a noble and high place.

Even though the polytheists are not happy with this reality, and even continue to obstruct it and destroy it if they can, it is the divine will of Allah that will prevail, and no power can hinder or prevent it. Allah says:

"(Such has been) the practice of Allah already in the past. You will never find in the practice of Allah any change." (al-Fath/48: 23)
text.34:
This verse explains that most leaders and priests of the Jews and Christians have been influenced by the love of wealth and position. Therefore, they do not hesitate to seize the wealth of others unjustly and openly hinder people from believing in the religion brought by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). Because if they allowed their followers to justify and accept the Islamic da'wah, they would certainly not be able to act arbitrarily towards them, and the influence and position they enjoyed would be lost. The leaders and priests of the Jews and Christians have taken various ways to take the wealth of others, including:

1.  Building tombs for prophets and priests and establishing churches named after them. Thus, they can receive votive gifts and endowments offered to the tombs and churches. Sometimes they place pictures of their saints or statues, and then the pictures and statues are worshiped. In order for their requests to be granted, they also give gifts of money and so on. Thus, a lot of money is collected, and the money is fully controlled by the priests. This is an act that contradicts the religion brought by the apostles because it leads to polytheism and taking people's wealth by using the names of prophets and saints.

2.  Christian priests receive money from their congregations in return for forgiving sins they have committed. A person who has sinned can be forgiven if he comes to the church to meet the priest and confesses before him all the sins and immoralities he has committed. They believe with full conviction that if the priest has forgiven his sins, it means that God has forgiven him because the priest is God's representative on earth. Those who have given money for atonement are given forgiveness cards, as if the card will later be shown to God in the afterlife on the Day of Judgment, showing that they are clean from all sins.

3.  Rewards for giving fatwas, either legalizing the forbidden or forbidding the lawful, according to the wishes of the king, ruler, and wealthy people. If officials and wealthy people want to take actions that contradict the truth, such as taking revenge and acting cruelly towards groups they consider obstacles to the implementation of their desires or they consider as enemies, they ask the priests to issue a fatwa that allows them to act arbitrarily towards those people, even though the fatwa contradicts their religious teachings, as if the religious teachings are ignored and as if the Torah is just a piece of paper that can be changed as they please. This is greatly condemned by Allah in His word:

   Say, "Who revealed the Scripture that Moses brought as a light and guidance for the people? You [Jews] make it into pages, disclosing [some of] it and concealing much. And you were taught that which you knew not - neither you nor your fathers." (al-An'am/6: 91)

4.  Taking the wealth of others who are not of the same nation or religion by carrying out fraud, betrayal, theft, and so on, on the grounds that Allah only forbids deception and betrayal against the Jews. As for those who are not of the same nation and religion as them, it is permissible. This is explained by Allah in His word:

   And among the People of the Scripture is he who, if you entrust him with a great amount [of wealth], he will return it to you. And among them is he who, if you entrust him with a [single] silver coin, he will not return it to you unless you are constantly standing over him [demanding it]. That is because they say, "There is no blame upon us concerning the unlearned." And they speak untruth about Allah while they know [it]. (Ali 'Imran/3: 75)

5.  Taking usury (riba). The Jews are very well known in this matter, because among their priests there are those who legalize it even though usury is forbidden in their book. There are also among the priests who issue fatwas that taking usury from the Jews is halal. Likewise, some Christian priests legalize some usury even though they forbid some others.

These are the ways they practice in taking and controlling the wealth of others for their own interests and to satisfy their desires and lusts. As for the ways they hinder people from the path of Allah, it is by damaging the aqidah and damaging the pure religious teachings. The Jews once worshiped the calf idol, once said that Uzair was the son of Allah, and often distorted the verses of Allah and changed them, according to their desires and lusts, as has been explained in the previous verses such as in Surah al-Baqarah, Ali 'Imran, an-Nisa' and al-Ma'idah. They openly denied Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) as a prophet, even though he was the bearer of the pure aqidah which was then damaged by the Jewish priests. Likewise, the Christians have distorted the aqidah brought by Prophet Isa (peace be upon him), so that they consider him as God. Therefore, both the Jews and Christians always oppose the teachings brought by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), even insulting him in various ways and opposing and denying the Al-Qur'anul Karim. They try with all their might to extinguish the light of Allah, but Allah has determined that He will perfect that light. All their efforts and endeavors meet with failure, but surely only the will of Allah will prevail and be carried out. Allah says:

   They want to extinguish the light of Allah with their mouths, but Allah refuses except to perfect His light, although the disbelievers dislike it. (At-Taubah/9: 32)

Such is the behavior of most of the Jewish and Christian priests. Because of their greedy and avaricious nature for material possessions, they collect as much as possible and use some of that wealth to hinder people from following the path of Allah. Therefore, Allah will throw them later in the hereafter into hell and will punish them with a very painful torment. Regarding the collection of this wealth and not spending it in the way of Allah, although it is addressed to the Jews and Christians, the mufassirin are of the opinion that this verse also includes the Muslims. So whoever, because of his greed and avarice, tries to collect wealth and then stores it and does not spend it in the way of Allah, then he is threatened by Allah to be put into hell, whether he is Jewish, Christian, or Muslim.

Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah, Abu Dawud, and al-Hakim from Ibn 'Abbas that after this verse was revealed, the Muslims felt burdened and said, "We do not have the heart if we do not leave for our children a little of our wealth." Umar said, "I will expand your wealth," then he went with Thauban to the Prophet and said to him, "O Prophet of Allah, this verse feels very heavy for your companions." The Messenger of Allah replied, "Indeed, Allah does not obligate zakat, except so that the wealth that remains in your hands becomes clean. Allah only establishes the law of inheritance for the wealth that still exists after your death." Umar said takbir upon the explanation of the Messenger of Allah, then the Prophet said to Umar, "I will tell you something that is best to be maintained, namely a righteous woman who, when a husband looks at her, he feels happy, and when ordered, she obeys him, and when he is elsewhere, the woman guards his honor."
text.35:
This verse explains that those who accumulate wealth and hoard it without spending a portion in the path of Allah (paying zakat), will be cast into Hell. All that wealth will be heated with fire and then branded on the foreheads of its owners, as well as their sides and backs, and it will be said to them, "This is your wealth that you hoarded." In connection with this, there is a hadith narrated from Abu Hurairah:

"There is no one who does not pay the zakat on his wealth but that his wealth on the Day of Resurrection will be made into pieces of fire and then branded on his sides, forehead, and back." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

Such is the fate of the Jews and Christians who accumulate wealth and hoard it, and use some of that wealth to obstruct the path of Allah. Likewise, such is the fate of a Muslim who does not pay the zakat on his wealth. The wealth itself will be made into an instrument of torture. How this happens, whether the wealth they acquired in the world is made into pieces of fire or is merely a representation, Allah knows best, because it is a matter of the unseen that is known only to Allah.
text.36:
This verse explains that Allah has determined the number of months to be twelve, ever since He created the heavens and the earth. What is meant by "month" here is the lunar month (Qamariah), because it is with the lunar calculation that Allah determines the time for performing obligatory (fardzu) and recommended (sunat) acts of worship, and several other provisions. Thus, performing the Hajj, fasting, the determination of the 'iddah (waiting period) of divorced women, and the duration of breastfeeding are determined by the lunar month.

Among the twelve months, there are four months designated as sacred months (bulan haram): Zulkaidah, Zulhijah, Muharram, and Rajab. These four months must be respected, and warfare is not permitted during this time. This provision also applied in the laws of Prophet Ibrahim and Prophet Ismail, up to the law brought by Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). One of the wisdoms behind the implementation of these sacred months, especially Zulkaidah, Zulhijah, and Muharram, is to ensure that the Hajj pilgrimage in Mecca can proceed peacefully. The time span between Zulkaidah and Muharram is sufficient to secure the implementation of the Hajj pilgrimage.

If anyone violates this provision, the violation is not because the provision has changed, but solely because of following the desires of their own whims, as the polytheists (musyrikin) have done. Usually, the Arabs were very obedient to this provision, so that if someone's brother or father was killed and they met the killer in one of these sacred months, they would not dare to seek revenge, out of respect for the sacred month. Even though the Arabs were very well-known for their spirit of seeking revenge and retaliation. That is the provision that must be fulfilled, because violating this provision is the same as oppressing oneself, because Allah has glorified it and made it months that must be respected. Unless we are betrayed or attacked in that sacred month, in which case it is obligatory to defend ourselves and retaliate against evil with evil. Allah says:

"They ask you about fighting during the sacred months. Say, "Fighting therein is a great [sin], but averting [people] from the way of Allah and disbelief in Him and [preventing access to] al-Masjid al-Haram and evicting its people therefrom are greater [evil] in the sight of Allah. And fitnah is greater than killing." And they will continue to fight you until they turn you back from your religion if they are able. And whoever of you reverts from his religion [to disbelief] and dies while he is a disbeliever - for those, their deeds have become worthless in this world and in the Hereafter, and those are the companions of the Fire, they will abide therein eternally." (al-Baqarah/2: 217)

This verse commands the Muslims to fight the polytheists because they broke the agreed-upon covenant and fought the Muslims. They fought the Muslims not because of revenge, tribal fanaticism, or seizing property as they used to do in the past against other tribes, but the main purpose was to destroy the religion brought by Prophet Muhammad and extinguish its light. Therefore, it is obligatory for every Muslim to rise up together to fight them until the religion of Islam is established and they are destroyed. Let the spirit of jihad be instilled in the hearts of every Muslim, as well as the determination and conviction that they will surely win because Allah always helps those who are pious to Him.
text.37:
This verse explains that postponing the sanctity (haram) of a month to the next month, such as postponing the month of Muharram to the month of Safar with the intention of allowing warfare in the month of Muharram, is an act of disbelief because it considers oneself equal to God in establishing laws.

It has been clear and acknowledged since the time of Prophet Ibrahim and Prophet Ismail that warfare is not permitted in the sacred months. However, because the polytheists could not control themselves from engaging in warfare for three consecutive months, namely Zulkaidah, Zulhijah, and Muharram, the sanctity of that month was shifted to another month so that they would have the opportunity to wage war in the month of Muharram.

This was their custom when they were in Mina. When the pilgrims gathered there, a leader from Bani Kinanah would stand and say, "I am the one whose decision cannot be rejected." The pilgrims would answer, "What you say is true, so postpone the month of Muharram for us to the month of Safar." Then the leader would make the month of Muharram permissible for them and make the month of Safar forbidden, and name the month of Muharram with another name, namely Nasiah.

Such is the nature of the polytheists; driven by desire and lust, they dare to make permissible what Allah has forbidden and have also dared to forbid what has been made permissible, because they have been influenced by the desires of Satan. And of course, people of that nature will not receive guidance from Allah.
text.38:
In the 9th year of Hijri, Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) ordered the Muslims to prepare for an attack by the Christians in Tabuk, a place located between Medina and Damascus, approximately 610 km from Medina and 692 km from Damascus. Currently, it is located in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, on the border with Jordan. This preparation order was based on news that reached the Muslims from the Nibthi people who were trading oil from the Levant, that the Romans together with the Arab Christians consisting of the Lakhm, Judzam and others, numbering approximately 40,000 people, complete with weapons and supplies and led by a great commander named Qubaz, were ready to attack the city of Medina and fight the Muslims. Their vanguard had already reached the border called Baqlas. It was the custom of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) when facing war, for the sake of benefit, to keep matters related to warfare secret. But this time, Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) openly informed the Muslims about the difficult and troublesome situation, the shortages, the long distance to be traveled, and the number of troops and the strength of the enemy to be faced, so that they would truly make solid preparations.

The Muslims whose faith was strong and unwavering, without considering the difficult and sad circumstances, prepared to await the departure command. The generous did not hesitate to donate their wealth for the sake of *jihad fisabilillah*. Uthman bin Affan donated 10,000 dinars, 300 camels, complete with weapons, and 50 horses. Abu Bakar as-Siddiq donated all his wealth, which was 4,000 dirhams. Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) asked, "Is there anything you have left for your family?" He replied, "What I have left for my family is Allah and His Messenger." Umar bin Khathab donated half of his wealth.

Ashim bin 'Adi donated 70 *wasaq* of dates (one *wasaq* = 60 *gantang*, 150 liters). The mothers also did not want to be left behind: their gold jewelry in the form of bracelets, earrings, necklaces, and so on, were donated with sincerity for the success of the Muslims' struggle. After everything was considered ready, Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) set out leading an expedition with 30,000 people towards Tabuk. Muhammad bin Maslamah was appointed by the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) to take care of the city of Medina and he entrusted Ali bin Abi Talib to take care of his household.

In addition, there were some Muslim soldiers who were lazy and reluctant to go to Tabuk with reasons including that they had not long returned from the Battle of Hunain and Thaif. Also, at that time the summer was very hot, it was a famine season, and it was difficult to obtain daily necessities such as food and so on. Because of the difficulty of getting food, a date was divided for two people to eat, while at that time fruits in Medina such as dates had begun to ripen, and would soon be harvested.

This verse condemns and curses the actions of people who are reluctant to fight even though the situation is indeed very difficult. From this event, it can be clearly seen who among the Muslims are truly believers, and who among them are hypocrites, who only pretend to believe. One of the signs that a person's faith is true is that he is willing to sacrifice his wealth and if necessary his life for *jihad* in the way of Allah, as Allah Almighty says:

Indeed, the true believers are those who believe in Allah and His Messenger and then doubt not, and strive with their wealth and their lives in the cause of Allah. They are the truthful. (al-hujurat/49: 15)

While the hypocrites who only pretend to believe, prioritize the pleasures of life in this world over the happiness in the hereafter which is eternal. Even though the pleasures of this world, no matter how great, have no meaning compared to the happiness in the hereafter. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said:

By Allah, this world (compared) to the hereafter is only like one of you dipping his finger into the sea, then lifting it. Then look at what is only carried by his finger. (Narrated by Muslim, Ahmad and at-Tirmidzi from al-Miswar)
text.39:
This verse threatens those who disobey the advice and commands of the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to go to war against the threat of the enemy. Their disobedience to the Prophet Muhammad's command to go to war to uphold the religion will not harm Allah Almighty in the slightest, nor will it benefit Him, as Allah Almighty says, as narrated by the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him:

"O My servants, you will never be able to inflict harm upon Me so as to trouble Me, nor will you be able to benefit Me so as to give Me help." (Narrated by Muslim from Abi Dharr al-Ghifari)
text.40:
This verse does not justify the assumptions of the polytheists, that the struggle of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) would not succeed if they did not help him. The Prophet would still be victorious because Allah would help him. This was proven when the Prophet Muhammad's house was tightly surrounded by the Quraysh who intended to kill him. The assassination was intended to prevent and stop the Islamic da'wah, which they feared would become increasingly influential. By the help and assistance of Allah Almighty, Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was able to escape from their tight encirclement, so that with a feeling of security he left his house towards a cave in Mount Thawr, his temporary hiding place, accompanied by his loyal companion Abu Bakr. Seeing the critical situation, Abu Bakr felt anxious and said, "O Messenger of Allah, by Allah, if one of them were to lift his foot, he would surely see us under his feet." Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) replied, "O Abu Bakr, do not grieve, indeed Allah is with us."

Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and Abu Bakr, while in the cave of Thawr, were always under the help and protection of Allah. Allah gave peace of mind to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and Abu Bakr, and provided assistance with soldiers they did not see, so that both were saved in the cave of Thawr, and the evil intentions of those people failed. Allah Almighty says:

And (remember) when those who disbelieved plotted against you to restrain you or kill you or evict you [from Makkah]. But they plan, and Allah plans. And Allah is the best of planners. (al-Anfal/8: 30)

And His saying:

Indeed, We will support Our messengers and those who believe during the life of this world. (Gafir/40: 51)

Allah Almighty always places the disbelievers at a low level, always defeated. And the word of Allah, which is religion based on tawhid, far from shirk, is always placed in a high place, surpassing others. Allah Almighty is All-Powerful and All-Mighty, nothing can defeat Him, All-Wise, placing things in their proper place. He is the One who always helps to make His Messenger (peace be upon him) victorious with His power, making His religion victorious over other religions, with His wisdom, as Allah Almighty says:

It is He who has sent His Messenger with guidance and the religion of truth to manifest it over all religion, although those who associate others with Allah dislike it. (at-Taubah/9: 33)
text.41:
This verse explains that when the safety of Muslims is threatened, fighting is no longer a recommendation, but an obligation, so no Muslim is justified in not participating in the expedition. Every healthy, adult, rich, and poor person is obligated to appear on the battlefield to defend Islam and uphold the truth. Those who are excused due to valid reasons are not obligated, such as being too old, physically weak, disabled, helpless, seriously ill, and so on, because they would become a burden if included. Allah SWT says:

"There is no blame upon the weak or upon the ill or upon those who do not find anything to spend [for the cause] if they are sincere to Allah and His Messenger." (at-Taubah/9: 91)

They are commanded to strive in jihad, guarding against enemy attacks, defending the homeland, donating their wealth and themselves to uphold justice, and exalting the word of Allah. Whether appearing on the battlefield or striving in jihad with wealth, with the intention of raising the status of the ummah and religion, if done sincerely, it will bring happiness in this world and the hereafter.
text.42:
This verse explains the background of why the hypocrites did not participate in the war, even though the order to wage war had been announced. Among the reasons for their reluctance was that going to war would involve traveling a long distance, in the summer, in a state of scarcity, and there was no guarantee of victory or obtaining spoils of war (ghanimah). They were pessimistic because they would be facing the trained, strong, and numerous Roman army.

If they were ordered to a nearby place that did not require them to exert themselves on the journey, and they were certain of victory and easily obtaining profit, they would certainly be willing and would not be reluctant to fight. To hide their hypocrisy, they would not hesitate to swear by the name of Allah that if they were able and had the capacity, they would certainly have gone with them. They uttered this oath as an excuse when the Muslims had returned safely from the Battle of Tabuk and were already in their midst, as Allah says:

They will make excuses to you when you have returned to them. (at-Taubah/9: 94)

They assumed that the false oath they uttered would benefit them and could cover up their hypocrisy, but in reality, that action only harmed them. In addition, a false oath is one of the major sins, as the Prophet Muhammad (saw) said:

The major sins are: associating partners with Allah, disobeying parents, killing a person, and taking a false oath. (Narrated by al-Bukhari from 'Abdullah bin 'Amr bin al-'Ash)

Allah (swt) knows the lies and falsehood of their oaths, and Allah will recompense them for all of that.
text.43:
According to a narration from Mujahid, this verse was revealed concerning the hypocrites who asked the Messenger of Allah for permission, using various excuses, not to go to war. In reality, whether permitted or not, they would still remain in Medina and would not participate in the battlefield.

Allah has forgiven the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, for granting permission to some hypocrites not to join the war, after they presented fabricated reasons, before there was a revelation from Allah Almighty giving approval for their request. If the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, had not fulfilled their request and had not permitted them, their secrets would have been revealed, because whether permitted or not, they would not have gone to the battlefield.
text.44: Those who believe in Allah and the Last Day will certainly not seek excuses to avoid fighting in defense of the religion and upholding the truth. Nor will they ask permission from the Messenger of Allah (saw) to refrain from striving in the path of Allah with their wealth and themselves. On the contrary, they are always ready to sacrifice their wealth, according to their ability, and even their lives are ready to be sacrificed. Allah (swt) knows those who are pious towards Him, namely those who always avoid things that cause Allah's wrath and do what pleases Him.
text.45: This verse explains that those who ask permission from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) to not participate in jihad without acceptable reasons are hypocrites who do not believe in Allah (SWT), do not acknowledge His Oneness, and do not believe in the Last Day. They think that spending wealth in the path of Allah is foolishness and a loss, and that engaging in jihad by sacrificing one's life is purely a loss and suffering. In their hearts, they harbor doubts about the truth of their religion. They are always confused and hesitant. They are willing to cooperate with the believers in easy matters, but in matters that are somewhat difficult and burdensome, such as fighting, they evade and seek various fabricated reasons to avoid or free themselves from this obligation.
text.46:
This verse clarifies the evidence of the falsity of their oaths and the falsehood of their words, namely the absence of any signs that they would participate in the war. If they truly intended to go to the battlefield, they would certainly have prepared the necessary equipment such as provisions, vehicles, weapons, and so on.

The non-participation of the hypocrites in the war was an advantage for the Muslims, because if they had joined the battlefield, they would certainly have stirred up discord among the Muslims and disrupted the ranks. That is why Allah made their intentions weak, anxious, and doubtful in their hearts, causing them to feel reluctant and unwilling to go, as if someone were saying to them in an angry tone, "Just stay with the children, women, weak people, and the sick, and don't go to the battlefield." These words pleased the hypocrites because they considered them to be in accordance with their will and desires, even though the words were spoken in a less than pleasant tone.
text.47: In this verse, Allah explains that even if the hypocrites who ask for permission were to go forth with the Muslims, they would not increase the tranquility and enthusiasm of the Muslims. On the contrary, they would disrupt the concentration of the Muslims, damage their unity, and weaken their steadfastness. Allah SWT knows those who are unjust and will give them a fitting recompense in the Hereafter.
text.48:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains that the efforts to disrupt the ranks, carried out by the hypocrites, had already been ongoing since the Battle of Uhud. During the Battle of Uhud, the leader of the hypocrites, namely 'Abdullah bin Ubay, persuaded a third of the Muslim army midway to Uhud, at a place called Syauth between Medina and Uhud, to withdraw from the war. According to Ibn Ubay, only foolish and insane people would want to participate in the war and die in vain. He then returned to Medina along with the hypocrites he had influenced. As for the two groups, namely Banu Salamah and Banu Haritsah, who were almost influenced and provoked by the propaganda spread by 'Abdullah bin Ubay, they were still protected by Allah SWT, so they were not affected and were saved from the slander. That is what is meant by the word of Allah:

"When two parties from among you were about to lose heart." (Ali-'Imran/3: 122)

However persistent the efforts of the hypocrites to paralyze the struggle of the Messenger of Allah SAW and his followers, in the end, the truth prevailed. The promise of Allah SWT came at the right time, and the religion of Allah achieved victory, towering high and with nothing higher than it. The city of Mecca was liberated, and people entered Islam in droves, even though all of that was disliked by the enemies of Allah. The word of Allah SWT:

"They want to extinguish the light of Allah with their mouths, but Allah refuses except to perfect His light, although the disbelievers dislike it." (at-Taubah/9: 32)
text.49:
Sabab Nuzul: Narrated by al-Wahidi in his book Asbab an-Nuzul that the Messenger of Allah said to Jad bin Qais, one of the leaders of the hypocrites, "O Jad, do you have the ability to face Bani Ashfar (the Romans)?" Jad replied, "It is better if the Messenger of Allah allows me to stay (in Medina) and not participate in the war, because as my people know, I am easily tempted by women. I am afraid that if I see their women, I will be attracted and unable to restrain my desires, so I will eventually fall into fitnah." With a heavy heart, the Messenger of Allah turned his face away and said, "I allow you to stay," and then this verse was revealed.

This verse explains that among the hypocrites, there were those who were not ashamed to fabricate excuses to ask the Messenger of Allah not to participate in the war and to be allowed to stay in Medina. They seemed to forget that the various excuses they made and showed were known to Allah, and Allah would reveal the secrets hidden in their hearts. They did not realize that the false reasons they put forward and the deception would plunge themselves into a valley of disaster and great sin. Their actions showed the weakness of their faith and revealed their hypocrisy. They will be plunged into hell because of the sins they have committed, namely, disbelief in Allah, refuting His verses, and denying His messengers. Allah says:

"No! Whoever earns evil and his sin has encompassed him - those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally." (al-Baqarah/2: 81)
text.50:
Sabab Nuzul: It is narrated that the hypocrites who remained in Medina and did not go to war always spread false news concerning the Prophet Muhammad and his companions. They said, "Muhammad and his companions are having difficulties on their journey and they are in danger." But not long after, it turned out that what the hypocrites spread was completely false. The Prophet Muhammad and his companions remained in good condition, lacking nothing. Based on this undeniable reality, the hatred of the hypocrites arose and this verse was revealed. (Fath al-Qadir 2/370).

This verse explains that one of the lies of the hypocrites was that when the Messenger of Allah and his companions obtained pleasant things such as *ghanimah* (spoils of war), victory, and others, as they had obtained in the Battle of Badr, they grumbled, feeling disappointed and restless, due to hatred and envy. Conversely, if the Prophet Muhammad and his companions experienced difficulties and defeat, as they experienced in the Battle of Uhud, they were happy and praised themselves for having made the decision to avoid war. They said, "Indeed, whenever we face something, we are very careful and consider it carefully far in advance."

Each boasted about the thoughts and considerations they had put forward. They praised their actions, feeling fortunate not to have gone to war and not to have experienced difficulties and destruction. Finally, they dispersed in a state of happiness and feeling joyful over the disaster that had befallen the Prophet Muhammad and his companions.
text.51:
This verse commands the Messenger of Allah to respond to the challenge of the hypocrites who rejoice when the Messenger of Allah and his companions are afflicted with difficulties and feel constricted when the Messenger of Allah and his companions obtain blessings, by saying, "What befalls us and what we obtain and experience are things that have been arranged and determined by Allah, namely things that have been recorded in Lauh Mahfudh in accordance with the sunnatullah that applies to His servants, both the blessings of victory and the disasters of defeat, everything happens according to the qadha and qadar from Allah and not according to the will and desire of any human being. Allah is our only protector, and to Him we trust and surrender ourselves, thus we never feel despair when afflicted with something unpleasant and do not feel arrogant and haughty when we obtain blessings and things that become our aspirations and ideals."

Allah says:

And whoever relies upon Allah - then He is sufficient for him. Indeed, Allah will accomplish His purpose. Allah has already set for everything a [decreed] extent. (Ath-Thalaq/65: 3)

And Allah says:

Have they not traveled through the earth and seen what was the end of those before them? Allah destroyed them. And for the disbelievers is something comparable. That is because Allah is the protector of those who have believed and because the disbelievers have no protector. (Muhammad/47: 10 and 11)
text.52:
This verse explains how the hypocrites await the destruction and ruin of the Prophet Muhammad and his companions, but they will not witness it, except for one of two things that are beneficial for the Messenger and the Muslims, namely victory or martyrdom. Meanwhile, the Messenger of Allah and his companions await one of two things that are detrimental and destructive to them, because they are still influenced by the poisonous whispers and invitations of Satan, so they are always in denial and disobedient. The two things meant are that at some point Allah will allow His Messenger to fight them until they surrender or experience destruction.

The ignorant hypocrites await what will befall the Prophet Muhammad and his companions. Conversely, the Prophet Muhammad awaits what punishment will befall them as long as they remain in denial and unwilling to come to their senses.
text.53:
This verse explains that no matter how the hypocrites spend their wealth to help the struggle of the believers, whether that wealth is given wholeheartedly, in accordance with Allah's command for their own salvation, or reluctantly, out of fear of the punishment that will befall them, Allah will not accept it. This is because they remain doubtful about the religion brought by the Great Prophet Muhammad and do not believe in the recompense in the Hereafter for all the deeds they do in this world. Allah will only accept good deeds if they are done not for show (riya) but with sincerity (ikhlas) and piety (taqwa) towards Allah. The Prophet Muhammad said:

"Indeed, Allah SWT will not accept any deed unless it is done with sincerity and intended solely for Allah." (Narrated by an-Nasa'i from Abu Umamah)

Allah says:

"Indeed, Allah only accepts from those who are righteous [i.e., who fear Him]." (al-Ma'idah/5: 27)
text.54: This verse explains that the reason the infaq (charitable spending) of the hypocrites is not accepted by Allah is because they persist in disbelief in Allah and His attributes, disbelief in the Messenger of Allah and the guidance and explanations he brought. Even when the hypocrites perform prayer (salat), they do so with laziness. They pray when in front of people, but when they are alone, they abandon and do not perform the prayer. They do not expect reward from their prayer, nor do they fear punishment for abandoning it. The prayer they perform is not because they believe in its obligation, but because of riya (showing off) and wanting to be seen and known that they also participate in prayer. When they spend their wealth to help the struggle of the Messenger of Allah and his companions, or other matters, they give it with reluctance, not willingly and sincerely, because they consider that their assistance will harm themselves, while benefiting the believers, and they are not among the believers.
text.55:
This verse indicates that believers should not be influenced and fascinated by abundant wealth and offspring that become their pride, because all that they boast about will only increase the torment they suffer in this world and in the hereafter.

They painstakingly accumulate wealth, regardless of the methods they employ. What is important to them is that wealth can be collected as much as possible by any means, even by methods not justified by religious teachings, because they assume that abundant wealth will bring them happiness in this world and in the hereafter.

In addition to the torment experienced in this world, they also feel a very painful torment at the end of their lives, because their souls will be taken with great difficulty and in a state of disbelief (kufr). A person who dies in a state of disbelief, all his deeds and efforts will be in vain and perish, as Allah says:

"That is their recompense: Hell, because they disbelieved..." (al-Kahf/18: 106)
text.56:
This verse explains to the Prophet Muhammad concerning the anxiety and worry of the hypocrites because they feared their secrets would be known by the believers. Therefore, they swore by the name of Allah to cover up the falsehood of their words, claiming they were on the side of the believers. Whereas, in reality, they did not believe; in fact, they were always enveloped by doubt and anxiety. They always stated something different from what was contained in their hearts because they were always in fear. Such was the behavior of the hypocrites when meeting with the believers, as Allah explained in His word:

And when they meet those who believe, they say, "We believe"; but when they are alone with their devils (leaders), they say, "Indeed, we are with you; we were only mockers." (al-Baqarah/2: 14)
text.57: This verse explains that the hypocrites do not want to associate with the believers because they are afraid and worried that their hypocrisy will be discovered, especially if they are invited to participate in fighting alongside the believers. Therefore, if they could find a place of refuge in the form of fortified caves in the hills or trenches to protect themselves from the retaliation of the believers, they would certainly flee to hide in those places because they are aware that their hypocrisy will eventually be known.
text.58:
Sabab Nuzul: Abu Said al-Khudri narrated that when the Messenger of Allah (saw) was distributing charity, Ibn Zi al-Khawaisirah at-Tamimi came and said, "Be just, O Messenger of Allah." The Prophet replied, "Woe to you! Who else will be just if I am not just?" Umar said, "Allow me to cut off his head!" The Prophet replied, "Leave him, he has many friends. Some of you will despise your prayer compared to their prayer, your fasting compared to their fasting. They will abandon the religion like an arrow leaving its bow." Then this verse was revealed. (Narrated by al-Bukhari).

This verse explains the existence of some hypocrites who criticized the Prophet Muhammad regarding his wisdom in distributing zakat to those who deserved to receive it. In an effort to hinder the development of Islam, they fabricated false accusations directed at the Prophet Muhammad with the intention of influencing Muslims who were still weak in faith. They accused the Prophet Muhammad of being unjust, biased, and showing favoritism in distributing zakat.

These hypocrites, if they were given zakat by the Prophet, they would accept it and remain silent, even though they were not among those who deserved to receive it because they only pretended to be poor. But when they were not given by the Prophet because they were not among those entitled to receive zakat, they immediately became angry and made accusations against the Prophet. Such an attitude shows that they only thought about their own interests. Such was, among other things, the behavior of those hypocrites.
text.59: If they truly believed in Allah, they would certainly not criticize or make accusations against the Messenger. They should be content and grateful to Allah for the distribution of that wealth, whether it concerns the distribution of spoils of war or zakat. They would believe that Allah is the place to beseech and the One who will grant mercy and sustenance to His creation.
text.60:
The *sadaqah* referred to in this verse is the obligatory *sadaqah* known as *zakat*, an obligation from Allah to Muslims who have met the conditions for paying *zakat*, for the sake of maintaining the welfare of the *ummah*. The legislation of *zakat* is stated in Allah's words:

"Take, [O, Muhammad], from their wealth a charity by which you purify them and cause them increase..." (at-Taubah/9: 103)

Thus, it is clear that *zakat* is legislated to cleanse oneself from wealth that may have been obtained in an improper manner, encouraging its owners to be grateful to Allah for the sustenance He has given. Those who are entitled to receive *zakat* in this verse are eight categories as follows:

First: The poor (*fakir*), namely those who have wealth and a livelihood that is insufficient and do not beg, according to Imam Shafi'i.

Second: The needy (*miskin*), namely those who have wealth or a livelihood but it is not sufficient for their needs, so they beg, degrading their self-esteem, according to Imam Shafi'i. According to Imam Abu Hanifah, *miskin* is what is called *fakir* according to Imam Shafi'i's understanding, and what is called *miskin* according to Imam Shafi'i is *fakir* according to Imam Abu Hanifah.

Third: Those who are employed to collect *zakat* (*amil zakat*), namely those who are assigned to collect, manage, and store *zakat* funds, whether they are tasked with collecting or storing *zakat* funds as treasurers or as administrators of bookkeeping, regarding both receipts and distribution (disbursement). This *amil* group receives a share of the *zakat* as compensation for their work. It is mentioned in a narration:

Ibn as-Sadi al-Maliki said, "Umar appointed me as a *zakat* collector. After I finished and handed over the collected *zakat* to him, he ordered that I be given a portion. Then I said that I did that for Allah. Then he replied, 'Take what has been given to you, because I used to be a *zakat* collector during the time of the Messenger of Allah, then the Messenger of Allah gave me a wage, so I answered as you answered. Then the Messenger of Allah said to me: "If you are given something without you asking for it, then eat (accept) it and give *sadaqah*." (Narrated by Ahmad, al-Bukhari and Muslim).

Fourth: Those whose hearts are to be reconciled (*muallaf*), namely those who need to have their hearts comforted in order to enter Islam firmly, or those who are feared to be hostile and disturb the Muslims, or those who are expected to provide assistance to the Muslims.

*Muallaf* are of three categories:

a. The influential non-believers who are expected (to embrace Islam), as was the treatment of Prophet Muhammad towards Safwan bin Umayah at the time of the conquest of Mecca. The Prophet gave Safwan security so that he could feel the goodness of the Islamic religion. The Prophet also gave him a camel along with what was on the camel's back, so that Safwan was finally interested in entering Islam consciously. He said, "Indeed, Muhammad gave me a lot when I saw him as the most hated person, so with his friendly treatment towards me, Muhammad became, in my view, the most beloved person." Thus, Safwan eventually became a good Muslim.

b. The poor non-believers who then embraced Islam until their faith was firm. To strengthen and affirm their faith, the Messenger of Allah once gave some of the spoils of war to those who were still weak in faith from among the people of Mecca, even though some of them were hypocrites.

c. Muslims who live in border areas with non-believers. They are given *zakat* because their vigilance is expected in defending the Muslim area and paying attention to the movements of the enemy.

Fifth: For freeing slaves. Islam eradicates slavery in a wise manner. In the context of freeing slaves, funds are provided from *zakat* which are used to buy slaves and free them, or given to a slave who has received a guarantee from his master to release himself by paying a certain amount of wealth. A slave like this is called a "mukatab". Like a hostage, a worker accused of murder can be released with money.

Al-Bara' bin 'Azib said, "A man came to the Messenger of Allah and said:

"Show me an act that brings me closer to Paradise and keeps me away from the fire of Hell." So the Messenger of Allah replied, "Free a slave or strive to release him." The man said, "O Messenger of Allah, are not the two things one (similar)?" The Prophet replied, "No, freeing a slave is that you alone free him, while releasing a slave is that you help pay his price (ransom)." (Narrated by Ahmad and al-Bukhari from al-Barra' bin 'Azib).

Sixth: Those who are in debt. This group consists of two levels:

a. Those who are in debt to meet their daily needs in a way that is not sinful. They are entitled to receive *zakat* if they do not have the ability to pay the debt for which they are responsible.

b. Those who are in debt for the public interest. They are entitled to receive *zakat* even if they are capable people (rich people).

Seventh: In the cause of Allah (*sabilillah*). The word "sabilillah" has two meanings. First, a specific meaning, namely people who voluntarily become soldiers doing *jihad*, defending the religion of Allah against non-believers who disturb the security of the Muslims. Second, a general meaning, namely all community-based actions aimed at obtaining Allah's pleasure, such as: providing public facilities, scholarships for education, and for *da'wah*.

The scholars of the four schools of thought adhere to the first meaning, but some scholars have the view that includes both the specific and general meanings based on the *ushul fiqh* rule:

"What is held is the generality of the meaning of the word (a *nash*), not the specificity of the reason (the *nash* was spoken/revealed)."

On this basis, the construction or maintenance of mosques and madrasas, as well as activities for scholars and *mubaligh*, can be taken from *zakat* funds.

Eighth: The traveler (*ibnu sabil*). A traveler who needs help even though he has wealth in his country. Such a traveler can be given assistance from *zakat* funds even if his trip is as a tourist as long as he does not intend to commit sin from his trip.

These eight categories are Allah's provisions that must be heeded by Muslims. Allah is All-Wise and All-Knowing as to who among them is capable and who needs help. Allah is All-Wise in regulating the provisions and guidance directed to those who are capable so that their souls become pure and grateful to Allah for the blessings given to them. The eight categories that have been explained in this verse can be divided into two categories:

a. First, the group that receives *zakat* directly becomes personal property, they are the poor, the needy, *amil*, those who bear debt, *muallaf* and travelers. The *zakat* given to them becomes their property.

b. Second, the group that receives *zakat* for the public interest. This group consists of institutions and bodies, consisting of:

1. *Fi ar-Riqab*, namely efforts to free slaves. The *zakat* collecting body can directly or through certain organizations buy all the slaves that will be sold by their owners or that are in the slave markets to be freed.

2. *Fi Sabilillah*, namely all religious interests that are of a general nature as explained above.

Some commentators, supported by *Fiqh* scholars, view that only four categories from these eight categories belong to the first category, namely: the poor, the needy, *amil*, and *muallaf*. While the last four categories, namely: freeing slaves, freeing debts for the public interest, *fi sabilillah* and *ibnu sabil* belong to the second category, namely for the public good.
text.61:
Sabab Nuzul: According to a narration from Ibn Abi Hatim from as-Suddi, there was once a gathering among the hypocrites, including Jullas bin Suwaid bin Samit, Mikhasi bin Umar, and Wadiah bin Thabit. Some of them intended to slander the Prophet, but some others forbade it, fearing that it would reach the Prophet and cause them trouble. Then one of them said, "Muhammad is too trusting of whatever he hears, as long as we swear to convince him." Then this verse was revealed.

This verse explains that among the hypocrites were those who harmed the Prophet Muhammad. They slandered him and said that the Prophet was too easily influenced without thinking and investigating the truth of what he heard. Their accusation was based on the fact that the Prophet Muhammad treated them similarly to how he treated the believers in general. This showed that the Prophet could be influenced, just as he was influenced by their words. On this basis, they saw a weakness in the Prophet Muhammad, and such a weakness, if found in a ruler like a king, would be very dangerous for the king, and people who were good at flattery would gather around the king to influence the decisions he made.

After Allah explained the assumption that was developing among the hypocrites, the Prophet Muhammad was commanded to listen to everything that was conveyed to him, but then to continue with an investigation into its truth. This command aimed to prevent the Prophet Muhammad from being deceived by people who wanted to flatter or curry favor. At the end of this verse, Allah explains the most severe punishment that will be the penalty for the hypocrites who accuse the Prophet with inappropriate accusations.

From a legal perspective, this verse prohibits harming the Messenger, both during his lifetime and after his death. Harming the Messenger during his lifetime can take the form of:

a. Doubting his prophethood or considering him a sorcerer. People who harm the Messenger in this way are considered disbelievers because they deny his prophethood.

b. Disturbing the peace of his household, such as visiting for too long or speaking in his presence in a loud voice. Such actions are haram, as stated in the Qur'an. Allah says:

Indeed, that [behavior] was troubling the Prophet, and he was shy of [dismissing] you. (al-Ahzab/33: 53)

And His saying:

O you who have believed, do not raise your voices above the voice of the Prophet or speak loudly to him as you speak loudly to one another, lest your deeds become worthless while you perceive not. (al-hujurat/49: 2)

Harming the Messenger after his death is the same as harming him during his lifetime, such as slandering his parents and family or insulting and denigrating them. A person's faith in the Messenger creates love for him. A person who loves something will certainly always view what he loves with respect because it is considered noble.
text.62:
Sabab Nuzul: Narrated by Ibn Mundhir from Qatadah regarding the *sabab nuzul* (reason for revelation) of this verse, Qatadah said, "We were informed that a man from among the hypocrites spoke about the group who did not participate in the Battle of Tabuk, regarding whom a specific verse was revealed. The man said, "By Allah, those who did not participate in the battle are indeed the chosen ones and the noble ones. If what Muhammad says is true, then they are worse than donkeys." A man from among the Muslims heard the man's words and said (in response to the hypocrites), "By Allah, what Muhammad says is true, and you are more vile than a *himar* (donkey)." The Muslim man went to the Messenger of Allah to tell him about the incident. The hypocrites were brought before the Prophet, and the Prophet said, "What prompted you to say such a thing?" The hypocrite denied his statement and cursed himself, swearing that he had never said such a thing. The Muslim man said, "O my Lord, vindicate the truthful and expose the liar," and then this verse was revealed.

This verse explains the habits of the hypocrites, just like those who commit a mistake, such as stealing and killing. They always feel troubled because they are always haunted by the consequences of their bad deeds, and they fear that their lies will be discovered by the Muslims. They often swear oaths as a way to cover up their crimes and lies.

Such is the behavior of the hypocrites; they swear oaths to convince the believers that what they say about their bad behavior, whether opposing or disparaging the Messenger of Allah, is not true. This is intended to make the believers acknowledge that they are innocent of all accusations. They often swear oaths with the intention of pleasing the Messenger and gaining the trust of the believers so that they receive protection from the believers; they should instead strive to gain the pleasure of God and His Messenger with sincere faith, far from hypocrisy and doubt, if they truly want to be believers. Even though the believers can be convinced by swearing oaths, and their lies are not revealed, Allah SWT still knows everything they do and everything that is still hidden in their hearts. When it is in the best interest, Allah reveals to the Messenger a *wahyu* (revelation) that explains everything they do.
text.63: The hypocrites should immediately realize because it is impossible for them not to know that fabricating accusations against the Messenger, such as accusing him of being unfair in distributing zakat or accusing the Messenger of being fond of listening to reports without verifying their truth, is an act of opposing Allah and His Messenger. Those who do such things will receive the reward of hellfire, abiding therein forever. This kind of torment is a great humiliation that should certainly be feared and avoided.
text.64: This verse describes the behavior of the hypocrites that was revealed during the Battle of Tabuk. They were worried that a verse or surah would be revealed that explained everything they had done. Therefore, Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad to tell them to continue the mockery they were doing. The hypocrites are people who have no principles, they are between faith and disbelief, they do not believe in the truth of the revelation that was revealed to the Messenger, they are between anxiety and hope. If they had explicitly denied the Messenger, they would not have been anxious. Likewise, if they had explicitly believed in the Messenger. Because their position is between faith and disbelief and they always criticize and mock the Prophet and the believers, their worry and anxiety arise lest Allah reveal more verses that expose their shame and explain everything that is in them, even if they keep it in their hearts.
text.65:
Sabab Nuzul: The reason for the revelation of this verse is closely related to the Battle of Tabuk, as narrated by Ibn Mundhir from Qatadah. During the Battle of Tabuk, the Messenger of Allah saw a group of people in front of him saying, "Does this man (Muhammad) expect to obtain palaces and fortresses in the land of Syria? Impossible, impossible." Allah informed His Prophet of what this group of people was saying, so Muhammad said, "You have said such and such." They replied, "O Prophet of Allah, we were only joking and playing around," then this verse was revealed.

This verse describes to the Prophet Muhammad the behavior of the hypocrites when the Prophet Muhammad asked them about their statements, which were accusations deliberately thrown at Muhammad, stating that the Prophet was seeking influence, power, and wealth. They would surely answer that their words were only a joke. They thought that the Prophet Muhammad could forgive and accept the excuse they put forward. But Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad to say to the hypocrites that it is not appropriate for them to mock Allah, His verses, and His Messenger. Such actions are excessive and no one does them except those who disbelieve in Allah.
text.66: This verse explains that it is useless for them to apologize by presenting excuses as mentioned in verse 65 because indeed, the hypocrites have become disbelievers after believing. They mocked the Prophet and looked down upon him. Such an attitude towards the Messenger demonstrates the emptiness of their souls from faith. They have committed a very great sin because they deliberately insulted the Prophet and denied Allah. However, if those hypocrites were willing to repent with genuine faith, like Makhsyi bin Humair, Allah would surely accept their repentance, and Allah will continue to punish the hypocrites who are still wallowing in hypocrisy.
text.67:
This verse explains the similarities between hypocrites, both men and women, regarding their characteristics, morals, and actions. Each encourages the other to commit evil, as explained by the Prophet:

"The signs of a hypocrite are three: When he speaks, he lies; when he makes a promise, he breaks it; and when he is entrusted, he betrays." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah).

Hypocrites each forbid one another from doing good, such as engaging in jihad and spending wealth on social causes, especially in the path of Allah (sabil), as Allah says:

"They are the ones who say, "Do not spend on those who are with the Messenger of Allah until they disband [and leave him]." (al-Munafiqun/63: 7)

All of this is because they have forgotten the greatness of Allah, forgotten His religious guidance and His punishment. More specifically, they have forgotten to draw closer to Allah by obeying His commands and avoiding His prohibitions, just as the obligation to be grateful for the blessings given by God does not cross their minds, so they follow the desires of their souls and the temptations of Satan. It is only fitting that Allah forgets them by distancing them from the grace of His guidance (taufik) in this world and the reward of merit in the Hereafter. Indeed, hypocrites who persist in their hypocrisy are the most wicked people in this world, even lower than ordinary disbelievers, because disbelievers openly conceal their hearts from the oneness or existence of God. This is different from hypocrites who deliberately conceal their faults, whether regarding creed (akidah) or morals and behavior that deviates far from the pure human nature, by pretending to be believers.
text.68: This verse explains God's threat to the hypocrites, both men and women, and His threat to the disbelievers. Allah threatens them with the torment of Hellfire, and they will abide therein forever. They receive God's curse in this world and in the Hereafter, and they are not entitled to Allah's mercy. God's torment continuously befalls them, both physical torment and endless inner torment. They cannot see the face of Allah because seeing the face of Allah is not permitted for those who deny Him.
text.69:
This verse explains that the hypocrites who harm the Prophet Muhammad and the believers are no different from the hypocrites who lived in the past. If, during the time of the Prophet Muhammad, they were deceived by worldly wealth and influenced by their children, then similarly, the hypocrites of the past were when facing the messengers of Allah. They possessed sufficient strength, material wealth, and many children, which caused them to be deceived by the pleasures of worldly life. They were always influenced by the desire for a luxurious life and wanted to be free to do as they pleased to satisfy their desires.

It is understandable that the hypocrites of the past behaved in this way because the factors that led them to evil were more numerous, as they possessed strength and wealth. This is different from the hypocrites in the time of the Prophet Muhammad; besides the decrease in strength and material wealth, the factors that led them to do good were more numerous. All the deeds of the hypocrites, even good deeds, are in vain in this world and the hereafter because they do them without sincerity. They should have been among the fortunate because they also participated in social work, but they forgot that for a good deed to be accepted, it must be accompanied by honesty and sincerity. Their mistake is described in Allah's words:

Say, [O Muhammad], "Shall we [believers] inform you of the greatest losers as to [their] deeds? [They are] those whose effort is lost in worldly life, while they think that they are doing well in work." (al-Kahf/18: 103-104)
text.70: In this verse, Allah reproaches the hypocrites for not knowing the stories of past peoples, such as the people of Prophet Noah, the 'Ad and Thamud, the people of Abraham, the inhabitants of Madyan, and the people of Lot. To them, Allah sent His messengers carrying guidance from Allah, but they met these messengers of Allah with a defiant attitude, so Allah sent down upon them punishment such as the flood that drowned the people of Noah, the wind that destroyed the 'Ad, and the thunder that destroyed the Thamud. This does not mean that Allah was unjust to them, because it contradicts the attribute of Allah's justice, which never wrongs His servants, but they wronged themselves because they did not heed the guidance of Allah brought by His messengers. *Sunnatullah* will not change; just as Allah inflicted punishment on those who opposed His messengers in the past, surely in the present Allah will punish those who are guilty if they do not repent.
text.71:
This verse explains that believing men and women are protectors of one another. As believers, they defend other believers because of their religious connection. Women, as believing women, also defend their brothers from among the believing men because of their shared faith, in accordance with their feminine nature. The wives of the Prophet and the wives of the companions also went to the battlefield with the Islamic army to provide drinking water and prepare food because believers are bound to one another by the bond of faith, which awakens a sense of brotherhood, unity, mutual love, and mutual help. All of this is driven by a spirit of camaraderie that makes them like one body or one building that strengthens one another in upholding justice and exalting the word of Allah. Such characteristics of believers are often stated in the hadiths of the Prophet Muhammad, including his saying:

"The parable of the believers in their mutual love, compassion, and support is like one body. If one part of the body suffers, the whole body feels feverish and sleepless." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Numan bin Bashir).

This trait of mutual defense is not found in hypocrites because they are enveloped by doubt and cowardice. Their brotherhood is merely a matter of lip service, as stated in Allah's word:

"Have you not observed those who are hypocrites, saying to their brothers who disbelieve among the People of the Scripture, "If you are expelled, we will surely leave with you, and we will not obey, in regard to you, anyone - ever; and if you are fought, we will surely aid you." But Allah is witness that they are liars. If they are expelled, they will not leave with them, and if they are fought, they will not aid them. And if they were to aid them, they would surely turn their backs; then they would not be victorious." (al-hasyr/59: 11 - 12)

The characteristics possessed by believers differ from the characteristics of hypocrites in the following ways:

a. Believers always enjoin good and forbid evil, while hypocrites always enjoin evil and forbid good.

b. Believers perform prayer with humility and a sincere heart, while hypocrites perform prayer reluctantly and for show (riya).

c. Believers, in addition to paying zakat, always have open hands to create the welfare of the ummah and provide social contributions, while hypocrites are stingy. If they give zakat or charity, it is because of riya, not because of sincerity to Allah, as stated in Allah's word:

"And nothing prevents their expenditures from being accepted from them except that they have disbelieved in Allah and His Messenger and that they come not to prayer except while they are lazy and that they do not spend except while they are unwilling." (at-Taubah/9: 54)

d. Believers are always obedient to Allah by abandoning acts of disobedience and carrying out all commands according to their ability, while hypocrites continuously commit acts of disobedience.

The end of this verse affirms that Allah will surely bestow His mercy, both in this world and in the Hereafter, upon the believers, while the previous verses stated that Allah cursed the hypocrites and threatened them with the fire of Hell. Indeed, Allah is Almighty; no one can reject His punishment. He is All-Wise, bestowing His mercy and grace upon whomever He wills, according to the deeds they have done.
text.72:
In this verse, Allah promises believing men and women Paradise as a reward for their good deeds. This Paradise is a beautiful garden filled with pleasures that have never been seen by the eye, nor heard by the ear, nor even crossed the heart. Everything seen and heard is foreign and new, making it difficult to compare because there is no equivalent in the world. It is a garden shaded by trees where rivers flow that do not resemble the rivers of this world, neither in color nor in taste. Those who dwell within it will reside there forever. The Prophet's saying explains about Paradise:

In Paradise, there are one hundred levels. Allah has prepared them for those who strive in the cause of Allah's religion. The distance between one level and another is like the distance between the heavens and the earth. When you ask Allah, ask for Paradise Firdaus, because it is the best and highest Paradise, from which the rivers of Paradise spring forth, and above it is the Throne of the Lord. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah).

Humans consist of body and soul. Paradise, with all its contents, provides the highest pleasure to the physical body, and Allah's pleasure provides the highest pleasure to the human soul. These two kinds of blessings are the gifts of God that He has promised to believing men and women. This is Allah's bounty, which is a great and unparalleled victory that can only be achieved by those who believe and do righteous deeds.
text.73:
This verse contains a command to the Prophet Muhammad to wage jihad against the disbelievers and the hypocrites and to treat them harshly. Waging jihad against the disbelievers is with the sword, while waging jihad against the hypocrites is by making them aware in the best possible way by presenting the necessary arguments (hujjah). Disbelievers, such as the Jews, hurt the Prophet in ways that hurt his feelings; they greeted the Prophet by changing the word "Assalamualaikum" to "Assamulaikum," an expression that means "Death be upon you too," and the Prophet would certainly reply with the words: "Waalaikum" which means "Death be upon you too." In addition, they often violated agreements. Towards the hypocrites, the Prophet always treated them gently, as he treated the believers. But on the contrary, the hypocrites always hurt the Prophet, for example by launching accusations stating that the Prophet was biased in distributing spoils of war and zakat. The Prophet easily believed reports without investigating them, and so on, which was meant to mock the Prophet. Therefore, Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad to act harshly towards them with the intention of teaching them a lesson in the hope that they would become aware.

The harsh attitude that the Prophet implemented was a strategy arranged by Allah, and in reality, it was successful. With such treatment, many disbelievers and hypocrites repented and returned to faith. But those who were still unaware because they were swept away and drowned in hypocrisy or disbelief, their place is Hell (Jahanam) forever, the worst place in the Hereafter.
text.74:
Sabab Nuzul: Narrated by Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari, ath-Thabrani, and Abu Syaikh Ibn Mardawaihi that when the Messenger of Allah was sitting under the shade of a tree, he said, "A man will come to you whose eyes look like the eyes of a devil.
