When he comes, do not speak." Then suddenly a man appeared whose eyes were sky blue, and the Messenger of Allah called him and said, "On what basis do you and your companions revile me?" Then the man left and returned with his companions, swearing by Allah that they had never uttered what the Prophet had asked; so the Prophet forgave them, and then this verse was revealed.

Those hypocrites swore by Allah to convince the believers and the Prophet Muhammad that what was reported to the Prophet about the deceit "which degraded the dignity of the Prophet Muhammad, or diminished the holiness of Allah" that they uttered was not true and was merely slander. They did not admit to having uttered words of disbelief against the Prophet Muhammad. Allah refuted their statement even though they swore by Allah. Those who have uttered words of disbelief have apostatized and become disbelievers again after Islam because they have gone too far to destroy the Prophet.

As for their failed attempt to trap the Prophet when returning from the Battle of Tabuk, it was when the Prophet was heading to Medina. On the way, several hypocrites conspired to harm the Messenger of Allah. They made a secret decision to throw the Prophet from one of the hills. When they arrived at the hill, they waited for the Prophet's arrival. When the Prophet came to them (who were waiting), the Prophet was informed of their plan, so the Prophet said, "Whoever among you wants to take the valley road, that is more pleasing to you." The Messenger of Allah himself took the road on the hill, and the rest of the group took the valley road except for those who intended to plot against the Prophet. When they heard that the Messenger would take the hill road, they prepared and disguised themselves by covering their faces. Indeed, they had resolved to commit an evil deed. The Messenger of Allah called Hudhaifah al-Yamani and Ammar bin Yasir to walk with the Messenger of Allah, Ammar was assigned to hold the camel's rope, and Hudhaifah al-Yamani was assigned to drive the camel. In such a situation, suddenly the Prophet, along with Ammar and Hudzaifah, heard the sound of footsteps of people coming from behind, so the Messenger of Allah became angry and assigned Hudzaifah to stop them. After Hudzaifah saw the Messenger of Allah angry, he turned back, holding a stick in his hand. Hudzaifah faced those people and hit their vehicles with the stick. Hudzaifah saw those people disguised, which Hudzaifah considered just a normal act done by people who were traveling (musafir). When those people saw Hudzaifah, Allah made them afraid because they thought that their disguise and evil intentions had been discovered.

Therefore, the group immediately rejoined the group. Hudzaifah returned to the Messenger of Allah, then the Messenger ordered Hudzaifah to whip his camel, and ordered Ammar to walk behind so that the Messenger of Allah could pass the hill safely. Then the Prophet said to Hudzaifah, "Do you recognize any of the riders?" He replied, "I know the camel of so-and-so. The night was too dark and I came to them where they were wearing disguises." The Messenger of Allah said, "They had planned a plot to walk with me and when they reached the hill, they would throw me." Hudzaifah said, "Won't you (O Messenger of Allah) give an order where we will quickly cut off their necks?" The Messenger of Allah replied:

No, I do not want to be the talk of the people that Muhammad has killed his companions. (Tafsir Ibn Kathir, 2/461)

Then the Prophet revealed to Hudzaifah and Ammar the names of the people who conspired so that they both would keep it a secret. Such was the evil event committed by the hypocrites that was revealed by the verse.

The hypocrites are Muslims whose faith is only outwardly, not inwardly. They are hostile to the Messenger and the believers in a very cunning way as enemies in disguise. They are very dangerous to Islam. However, the Prophet treated them as he treated the believers because faith is in the heart. Only Allah knows the affairs of the heart. Therefore, a punishment can only be decided based on the outward evidence that exists.

The hypocrites are treated as believers. They are given zakat as well as spoils of war (ghanimah). Most of them are from the less fortunate (poor) as are the Ansar. By embracing Islam, they can enjoy the wealth of this world. Ideally, if they were aware, they would abandon their hypocritical traits and be grateful to Allah by repenting to Him. Because through Islam they gain worldly benefits, which are the purpose of their lives. But they do not realize it. In fact, they are not satisfied with receiving the benefits and wealth that are the blessings of Allah from the distribution of spoils of war (ghanimah) or zakat.

Such is the state of a person who has lost his mind. If they repent from hypocrisy and evil deeds, whether in words or deeds, then their repentance will bring goodness to them in this world and in the hereafter. In this world, they will become true Muslims with pure faith. They will become people who trust in Allah and are patient with His trials and do many good deeds to achieve happiness in the hereafter and they will support each other, help each other, treat each other kindly with those who entered Islam earlier. In the hereafter, they will receive Allah's grace in the form of paradise as promised by Allah to the believers. But if they do not repent, turn away from Allah's guidance, and they remain in hypocrisy, then Allah will punish them in this world, such as their hearts always being in anxiety, restlessness and worry as stated in Allah's word:

If they could find a refuge or caves or any place to enter [and hide], they would turn to it while they run heedlessly. (at-Taubah/9: 57)

In the hereafter, they will receive what Allah has threatened, namely the lowest level of hellfire where they will abide forever as stated in Allah's word:

Indeed, the hypocrites will be in the lowest depths of the Fire - and never will you find for them a helper - Except for those who repent, correct [themselves], hold fast to Allāh, and are sincere in their religion for Allāh, for those will be with the believers. And Allāh will grant the believers a great reward. (an-Nisa'/4: 145-146)

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that the hypocrites will not have a defender in this world or in the hereafter, because no human being can help anyone who has received humiliation from Allah.
text.75: This verse explains the characteristics of hypocrites who like to make grand promises, daring to swear by the name of Allah to strengthen their promises. They promise to be generous, charitable, and good people. However, they easily break their promises. Such behavior can be found in a segment of humanity at all times and in all places.
text.76: In this verse, Allah explains that if their intentions have succeeded and what they asked for has been granted, they are not ashamed to turn away, break their promises, and disobey Allah. When they have become wealthy, they do not become generous people, but they become even more stingy, unwilling to give charity, pay zakat, help those in need, support the development of the ummah, and other acts of virtue. They forget their promises that were spoken before Allah bestowed His favor upon them, even though they have been warned repeatedly. Whereas fulfilling promises is obligatory, especially if the promise is strengthened by swearing in the name of Allah.
text.77:
In this verse, Allah explains that the actions of the hypocrites like that will not benefit them, but will harm themselves. The act of breaking promises, being stingy, turning away from Allah, and disobeying Him will result in an increase of the disease of hypocrisy nesting in their hearts. Such a disease will persist until the end of their lives. Because if the disease of hypocrisy has become more severe, there is no hope for them to repent. It has become the Sunnah of Allah on this earth, that a person who has accustomed himself to breaking promises and lying a lot, then the disease of hypocrisy becomes increasingly ingrained in him. Likewise, if he accustoms himself to doing good deeds, having good morals, and being obedient in worship, then a strong faith will be planted in him. Therefore, Allah SWT commands the Muslims to be careful of the disease of hypocrisy. If you make a promise and strengthen it by mentioning the name of Allah, then strive to fulfill that promise. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

A person is considered a hypocrite if three characteristics are found in him, even if he prays, fasts, and claims to be a believer, namely: when he speaks, he lies; when he makes a promise, he breaks it; and when he is entrusted, he betrays. (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abu Hurairah)
text.78: In this verse, Allah swt warns the hypocrites that no matter how cleverly they keep secrets in their hearts and how cunningly they whisper to denigrate the believers and denigrate the Messenger of Allah, or whisper among themselves to arrange evil strategies in opposing the believers, Allah swt will know it. Nothing is hidden from Allah whatsoever, neither on earth nor in the heavens, nor what is hidden in the heart; Allah is All-Knowing of all that is hidden.
text.79:
Sabab Nuzul (Circumstances of Revelation): There are several narrations explaining the reason for the revelation of this verse, including what was quoted by al-Wahidi in the book Asbab an-Nuzul: narrated by al-Bazzar from Abu Hurairah, he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Give charity, for I will send an army to go to war (the Battle of Tabuk)." Then Abdurrahman bin Auf came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and said, "O Messenger of Allah, I have 4,000 dinars, two thousand of which I give as a loan to God and two thousand dinars for my household expenses." The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) replied, "May Allah bless you for what you have given, and bless what you have left behind." Then another man from the Ansar came, having two gantang (a unit of measurement) of dates, saying, "O Messenger of Allah, I have two gantang of dates, one gantang of which I give as charity and one gantang for my family." Witnessing this event, the hypocrites mocked, saying, "Abdurrahman bin Auf only gives his charity out of ostentation (riya)." As for the one who gave one gantang of dates, they mocked with the words, "Allah and His Messenger do not need this one gantang." Then this verse was revealed.

In this verse, Allah SWT explains how the hypocrites mocked and insulted the believers who, with full obedience, gave their charity to the Messenger of Allah for the funds of the Islamic army to fight. To those who gave a lot, they mocked with accusations of riya, and to those who gave a little, they also insulted them, even though the believers gave that charity with a sincere heart solely for Allah, hoping for Allah's pleasure.

Such mockery and insults from the hypocrites did not diminish the enthusiasm of the believers to struggle; rather, they themselves will be ruined. Allah SWT will humiliate and mock them, and for them is prepared a painful punishment in the Hereafter.
text.80:
Sabab Nuzul: From Urwah r.a. that 'Abdullah bin Ubay said, "If you do not give charity to Muhammad and his companions, they will surely leave him." 'Abdullah said, "The noble ones will surely expel the weak ones." Then Allah revealed, "Whether you ask forgiveness for them or do not ask forgiveness for them..." The Messenger said, "I will increase it seventy times." Then Allah revealed, "It is all the same to them whether you ask forgiveness for them or do not ask forgiveness for them. Allah will never forgive them."

This verse contains a warning, specifically addressed to the Prophet Muhammad saw and generally addressed to the believers. The attitude of the hypocrites towards the Messenger saw and the believers cannot be expected. They will remain in hypocrisy until death. It is of no benefit, whether forgiveness is sought for them or not, because Allah will not forgive their sins. Even if forgiveness is sought repeatedly, even up to seventy times, it will not succeed, because what causes them to be hypocritical is their denial of Allah and the Messenger. They are not sure that Allah knows all that is unseen, they do not believe in Allah's revelation conveyed to the Messenger of Allah saw, about the Day of Judgment, the Day of Resurrection and the Day of Recompense. They are not only classified as hypocrites, but also classified as the wicked (fasik), namely those who do not want to accept the truth and continuously rebel, doing what is beyond limits. So Allah will not give guidance to the wicked (fasik) group.
text.81:
This verse explains the situation of the hypocrites who were not included by the Prophet in the battle. This event occurred during the Battle of Tabuk, which was a battle that took place after the conquest of Mecca. This battle was the last battle fought by the Messenger of Allah (saw). Someone conveyed news to the Messenger of Allah that the Roman Empire had prepared its armed forces to attack the Muslims on the northern border of the Arabian Peninsula. At that time, it was the height of summer, and the distance from Medina to the border area was very far. The difficulties and hardships of the journey were numerous. At that time, the Muslims were in a situation of scarcity. The Messenger of Allah began to prepare an army to face the armed forces of the Roman Empire. The Messenger of Allah (saw) asked the wealthy for assistance to provide supplies for the war. So, assistance in the form of money and goods came from wealthy and generous people sincerely, because they wanted to exalt the word of Allah on the face of the earth. All the tribes that had embraced Islam had declared their obedience to participate in the war alongside the Messenger of Allah (saw). They had prepared themselves and their wealth for war.

They were not afraid of the scorching heat of the sun, nor were they afraid of hunger and thirst on the journey through the vast desert, to crush the tyrannical enemy.

Finally, the Messenger of Allah was able to gather his armed forces perfectly, totaling 30,000 people, including approximately 10,000 cavalry. The Messenger of Allah (saw) knew that 'Abdullah bin Ubay, the leader of the hypocrites, along with his followers, was also participating in the army. Therefore, the Messenger of Allah (saw) doubted the good intentions of the hypocrites, fearing that they would cause chaos in the middle of the journey, so the Messenger of Allah (saw) ordered them to stay in Medina and not participate in the war.

They are the ones referred to in this verse, that they felt happy and fortunate not to be included by the Messenger of Allah in the war in Tabuk. In reality, their hearts did not want to fight, either with their wealth or with themselves, to uphold the religion of Allah. It did not even cross their minds that participating in the war was a great advantage. But they did the opposite; they stirred up trouble and weakened the fighting spirit of the Muslims. They told their friends not to participate in the war. All the difficulties such as heat and scorching sun, the long journey, the lack of supplies and others, they always used as propaganda to hinder the Muslims from fighting and to extinguish the spirit of struggle.

But all of that did not weaken the spirit of the Muslims, but rather increased their enthusiasm and strength, so that in the end the Muslims returned safely from the Battle of Tabuk, after the enemy retreated in fear. The Messenger of Allah was commanded to convey to the hypocrites that the fire of Hell that they would suffer later would be hotter if they would only understand.
text.82:
This verse explains that the hypocrites deserve to weep more than laugh when considering their fate and sins in this world and the hereafter, because they will receive a painful torment, in accordance with their deeds in this world. In this world, they suffer humiliation and loss because of their own actions, namely insulting and mocking the believers, creating malicious propaganda to hinder Muslims and break the spirit of struggle. Meanwhile, in the hereafter, they will carry many sins and receive no forgiveness from Allah swt. This is also in accordance with the words of the Prophet Muhammad addressed to the believers.

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"If you knew what I know, you would laugh little and weep much, the spread of hypocrisy and the disappearance of trustworthiness, the removal of mercy, the honest person is accused and the dishonest person is trusted. Chaos grips you, and trials grip the situation, becoming as dark as a pitch-black night." (Narrated by al-Hakim from Abu Hurairah)
text.83: In this verse, Allah swt warns the Messenger of Allah to be cautious of the hypocrites when they return from the Battle of Tabuk. These hypocrites will plan to apologize to the Messenger of Allah and express their regret for not being able to participate in the battle with the Prophet to Tabuk. In fact, they felt fortunate not to have participated in the battle to Tabuk and avoided danger. But after the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims returned safely from the battlefield, they felt ashamed and humiliated, and promised in their hearts that they would participate in the battle with the Messenger of Allah. So Allah swt reminds the Prophet that these hypocrites should not be given permission to participate in the battle because they still will not be honest in the war. They will certainly take various actions to undermine the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims. Therefore, the Messenger of Allah was commanded to state firmly that they were not justified in participating in the battle with the Messenger of Allah forever. They would not be able to fight the enemy with the Messenger of Allah as the Muslims did, who willingly sacrificed their wealth and lives to fight *fisabilillah*. Their attitude when facing the Battle of Tabuk showed that they preferred not to participate in the battle and stay in Medina with the excused people, such as children, women, and the elderly who were already weak.
text.84:
In this verse, Allah swt forbids praying over the deceased bodies of hypocrites. He also forbids praying at their graves after they have been buried, as the Messenger of Allah used to do for believers who had been buried, as mentioned in the following hadith:

When the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had finished burying a deceased person, he would stand at the grave and say, "Seek forgiveness for your brother and pray that he remains steadfast (in faith), for he is now being questioned." (Narrated by Abu Dawud and al-Bazzar from 'Uthman)

The event that occurred with 'Abdullah bin Ubay was quite frightening for the other hypocrites, a severe humiliation inflicted upon them. But they remained in their hypocrisy. This is a punishment for them in this world, because they always deny Allah and His Messenger. They belong to the people who are *fasiq* (deviant), too bold in playing with the commands and prohibitions of Allah.

(85) This verse is almost identical in wording to verse 55 in this surah. So in this verse, Allah swt repeats it again, so that the Muslims are not influenced by the wealth and possessions of the hypocrites. Likewise, they should not be influenced by their children. If some of them are rich, have a lot of wealth, many children and descendants, all of that will not make them happy and will not save them from the punishment of Allah.

All of that will trouble them, making them oppressed and miserable because of it. How they struggle in seeking wealth and possessions, so too are they made miserable by it. There are always events that happen because of their wealth and possessions, and their children are enough to make them feel as if they are receiving worldly torment. So their wealth and possessions and their children are no longer a blessing, but a torment for them. They will not receive any help from their wealth and children. There is no benefit at all, and in the end they die in disbelief.
text.85:
This verse is almost identical in wording to verse 55 in this surah. Therefore, in this verse, Allah swt repeats it again, so that the Muslims are not influenced by the wealth and possessions of the hypocrites. Likewise, do not be influenced by their children. If some of them are rich, have much wealth, many children and descendants, all of that will not make them happy and will not save them from Allah's punishment.

All of that will trouble them, making them oppressed and miserable because of it. How they struggle in seeking wealth and riches, so too are they made troubled by it. There are always events that occur because of their wealth and riches, and their children are enough to make them feel as if they are receiving worldly torment. So their wealth and riches, as well as their children, are no longer a blessing, but become a torment for them. They will not receive any help from their wealth and children. There is no benefit at all, and in the end, they die in disbelief.
text.86:
This verse explains how weak the faith of the hypocrites is and how cowardly they are. This is not only found in ordinary people, but also in the wealthy. If a surah is revealed whose verses command belief and jihad alongside the Messenger of Allah, the wealthy among them would rush to the Messenger of Allah, asking permission not to participate in jihad and war. They are not ashamed to make up excuses to strengthen their requests to the Messenger of Allah (saw), even though they are capable and strong enough to engage in jihad in terms of health and ability. Lightly, they say, "Let us stay at home with the weak who do not participate in the war."

Such ways show that they love their pleasures and possessions more than they love Allah and His Messenger. A similar matter is also explained by Allah (swt) in His word:

"And those who believe say, "Why has a surah not been sent down (about the command of jihad)?" But when a surah is revealed that is clear in meaning and in which war is mentioned, you see those in whose hearts is disease looking at you with a look of one overcome by death. But that would have been better for them." (Muhammad/47:20)
text.87: This verse explains that the hypocrites were pleased not to participate in *jihad fisabilillah*. They preferred to stay with the weak people who were not strong enough to participate in war, namely the women who took care of the household. They felt no shame whatsoever in staying with the women who did not participate in the war. Even though they were strong, healthy, and capable of participating in the war. Even though many mocked and laughed at them, the mockery meant nothing to them, because they no longer felt shame. This is a sign that their faith is very weak and their hearts have been influenced by materialism. Therefore, Allah sealed their hearts, they did not want to accept the truth, lessons, and advice from anyone. The disease of hypocrisy has enveloped their entire hearts, so they cannot use sound reasoning to distinguish between what is right and what is wrong, what is beneficial and what is detrimental, that participating in *jihad* and war is an advantage and staying at home is detrimental and shameful.
text.88:
In this verse, Allah explains the vast difference between the characteristics of the Messenger and the believers on one hand, and the characteristics and behavior of the hypocrites on the other. The Messenger and the believers are happy and joyful to strive and fight with their wealth and themselves to defend and elevate the word of Allah, to spread His religion on the face of the earth. They love Allah more than they love their wealth and themselves. Their conviction is that if they live, they should live with dignity and honor, and if they die, they should die as martyrs on the battlefield. In the hearts of the believers, you will not find laziness, reluctance to fight, or stinginess in giving wealth in *jihad fisabilillah*.

They believe that *jihad fisabilillah* will bring many benefits to them and the Muslim community. These many benefits include victory, the elevation of the word of Allah, the establishment of justice and truth, in addition to obtaining spoils of war, and the expansion of Islamic power on the face of the earth. They also believe that they will receive happiness in this world and in the hereafter. In this world, they will be honorable and respected people, while in the hereafter they will receive the reward of Paradise, *Jannatunnaim*, which is full of eternal pleasure and enjoyment. Within it flow refreshing rivers. This abundant pleasure and happiness is given by Allah to the believers.
text.89:
In this verse, Allah explains the vast difference between the characteristics of the Messenger and the believers on one hand, and the characteristics and behavior of the hypocrites on the other. The Messenger and the believers are happy and joyful to strive and fight with their wealth and themselves to defend and elevate the word of Allah, to spread His religion on the face of this earth. They love Allah more than they love their wealth and themselves. Their conviction is that if they live, they should live with dignity and honor, and if they die, they should die as martyrs on the battlefield. In the hearts of the believers, you will not find laziness, reluctance to fight, or stinginess in giving wealth in *jihad fisabilillah*.

They believe that *jihad fisabilillah* will bring many benefits to them and the Muslim community. These many benefits include victory, the elevation of the word of Allah, the establishment of justice and truth, in addition to obtaining spoils of war, and the expansion of Islamic power on the face of the earth. They also believe that they will receive happiness in this world and in the hereafter. In this world, they will be honorable and respected people, while in the hereafter they will receive the reward of Paradise, *Jannatunnaim*, which is full of eternal pleasure and enjoyment. Within it flow refreshing rivers. This abundant pleasure and happiness is given by Allah to the believers.
text.90:
These verses explain the situation of the hypocrites who lived outside the city of Medina, residing in the villages of the desert dwellers, commonly called the Bedouin Arabs. They deliberately came before the Messenger of Allah to present reasons so that the Messenger of Allah would grant them permission not to participate in the war. This event is explained in a narration recounted by someone named adz-ahhak, which is: "A group of Bedouins from the Amir bin Thufail group came before the Messenger of Allah, saying, "O Prophet of Allah, we do not participate in the war with you, we are worried that our women, our children, and our livestock will be destroyed and robbed by criminals." Then the Messenger of Allah replied, "Allah has informed me about your situation; may Allah forgive and save you." They presented various reasons to the Messenger of Allah, some reasons were fabricated and some were genuine, so that they would be granted permission not to participate in the war.

Those who came before the Messenger of Allah presenting genuine reasons were from the believers, and those who came with fabricated reasons were from the hypocrites. There was another group, namely those who did not come before the Messenger of Allah to ask for permission. They deliberately sat and stayed at home, unwilling to participate in jihad and war. These are clearly among those who deny Allah and His Messenger. They are the severe and very dangerous hypocrites. According to the opinion of Umar bin Ala', both those who asked for permission by presenting fabricated reasons, and those who sat and stayed at home, unwilling to participate in jihad and war, both groups are equally bad and equally dangerous. Both groups are already included in the group of disbelievers who will receive a painful torment from Allah, both in this world and in the hereafter.
text.91:
Sabab Nuzul (Circumstances of Revelation): There are several narrations that explain the reason for the revelation of this verse. Among them is the narration explained by Ibn Abi Hatim from Zaid bin Thabit, who said, "I was the scribe of the revelation that was revealed to the Messenger of Allah. When I was writing Surah Bara'ah, then I put my pen on my ear, then a revelation came down commanding us to fight. When the Messenger of Allah was paying attention to the revelation that was revealed to him, suddenly a blind man came, saying, "O Messenger of Allah, how can I participate in the war, while I am blind?" Then this verse was revealed."

In this verse, it is explained that those who are permitted not to participate in the war are free from the obligation to participate in the war. These people are not considered guilty or sinful for abandoning the obligation to fight if they truly have a justifiable reason, and they present that reason honestly and sincerely, namely:

1.  The weak, namely those who are physically weak and unable to participate in the war, such as the elderly, women, and children, as well as the disabled, such as the blind, deaf, paralyzed, broken, and so on.

2.  The sick who are unable to participate in the war. But if they recover, they are obligated to participate in the war.

3.  The poor who do not have the means and provisions for war.

These three groups are free from the obligation to fight. However, because of their honesty and sincerity to Allah and His Messenger, they still feel obligated to perform other tasks such as guarding homes and villages, monitoring for spies and traitors, maintaining secrets, urging people to remain calm, doing good deeds, and praying that the believers who go to war are protected by Allah and achieve a glorious victory.

These three kinds of people who have reasons justified by Sharia, truly sincere, believing in Allah and obedient to the Messenger, are among those who do good. They are not among those who are guilty, sinful, and punished. At the end of this verse, it is explained that Allah is Most Forgiving, Most Merciful. This means that Allah's forgiveness is abundant and His mercy is vast towards His servants who are weak in fulfilling their obligations, as long as they are honest and sincere to Allah and to His Messenger.
text.92:
Sabab Nuzul: In a narration explained by Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari from Ibn 'Abbas, he said, "The Messenger of Allah ordered the believers to prepare to go to war. Then a group of his companions, named 'Abdullah bin Saffal al-Muzani, said, "O Messenger of Allah, provide us with vehicles (we are poor and do not have vehicles)." The Messenger of Allah replied, "By Allah, I am unable to provide vehicles that will carry you to the battlefield." Then this verse was revealed, and they all wept because they could not participate in the war, because vehicles and war equipment were very important if the battlefield was very far away." Vehicles are a very important piece of war equipment for all times. If in the past the vehicles needed were only camels, donkeys and horses, then in later times humans created high-speed vehicles that can be used for land, sea and air traffic.

With the revelation of this verse, the hearts of those who came before the Messenger of Allah were comforted, but their tears flowed because they could not participate in the war with the Messenger of Allah because they were poor and did not have vehicles. If the place of battle was not so far, they would have been willing to walk, because of their desire to perform jihad and seek the pleasure of Allah. Such is the spirit and soul of Islam that burns in the hearts of every Muslim and will never be extinguished. With such a spirit, Islam can stand firm and advance, and the word of Allah will soar high on this earth.

In this verse, another reason is explained that is justified by Sharia for someone who does not participate in war. The reason is that they do not have vehicles that can transport them to the battlefield, especially if the place to be reached is far away, which cannot be reached on foot, such as the Battle of Tabuk, which was very far and could only be reached by crossing the desert for days and weeks before arriving at the destination. So those who do not have vehicles are allowed not to participate; they are considered not guilty and not sinful if they stay at home.
text.93:
This verse clarifies that wealthy individuals who are capable, who came before the Messenger of Allah to request permission not to participate in battle, are not justified in abandoning the obligation of fighting. They are considered to be at fault and deserving of punishment for their transgression.

This is in contrast to the people mentioned in the verses above, namely those who have reasons justified by Islamic law (syara) and present them sincerely and honestly for not participating in battle, then they cannot be blamed at all. Wealthy people who are capable of fighting because they are able to provide provisions and transportation, have no reason to ask permission not to participate in battle. That is why they are said to be at fault and it is fitting that Allah seals their hearts, because they do not want to accept the truth in the slightest. Ultimately, they wallow in hardship and sin, while they do not know the consequences of the actions they have taken.
text.94:
In this verse, mention is made of the things that the Prophet and the Muslims would face after returning from the Battle of Tabuk, namely that the hypocrites who did not participate in the war without a valid reason would come to the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims to apologize for their absence on the battlefield. So Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad to say to those hypocrites that they did not need to apologize, because the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims would not believe the false reasons they put forward, because Allah had informed His Messenger and the Muslims of all the circumstances and bad characteristics of those hypocrites. Allah and His Messenger only pay attention to their subsequent attitudes and behavior, whether they have truly repented and abandoned their disbelief and returned to faith and obedience to Allah, or whether they will remain in that disbelief. Then they will be returned to the One Who knows all things hidden and manifest, and He will inform them of everything they have done while living in the world.

In other words, it is no longer useful for them to put forward various reasons for their absence on the battlefield, because all the secrets stored in their hearts are sufficiently known to the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims through Allah's revelation (wahyu). Furthermore, it is up to them. If they have truly realized their mistakes, then repented and asked forgiveness from Allah, then Allah will accept their repentance, and the Messenger of Allah will forgive them.
text.95:
In this verse, Allah explains to His Messenger that when he and the Muslims return from the battle, the hypocrites will come to him swearing by Allah (to strengthen what they say), so that the Messenger of Allah will turn away from them by ignoring their actions of not participating in the battle.

Then Allah commands His Messenger to truly turn away from the hypocrites as a form of humiliation for them. Next, Allah explains the reason why the Messenger of Allah must turn away from the hypocrites because they are impure (najis). This means that their attitudes and actions are filthy, so they must be avoided, like keeping clean cloth away from something impure. This is in line with what is stated in Allah's word:

"O you who have believed, indeed the polytheists are impure (in soul)." (at-Taubah/9: 28)

Finally, Allah states that the hypocrites' place of return in the Hereafter will be Hell, as a reward for what they have done during their lives in the world, namely the disbelief that has defiled them; and that impurity increases because of their turning away from the verses of Allah. Similar information will be found later in Allah's word:

"But as for those in whose hearts is disease, it will only increase them in evil in addition to their evil. And they will die while they are disbelievers." (at-Taubah/9: 125)
text.96:
This verse reaffirms that the hypocrites will swear by the name of Allah to apologize to the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims, so that he and the Muslims will be *rida* (pleased) with them and forgive all their mistakes. After that, Allah affirms that it is not fitting for the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims to be pleased and *rida* with the hypocrites, because Allah Himself is not pleased with the *fasiq* people.

Allah's wrath upon the hypocrites is due to their denial and their bad characteristics. If there are any among the believers who sympathize with the hypocrites, then that person will also be afflicted with Allah's wrath.

However, if the hypocrites repent and ask forgiveness from Allah, and abandon hypocrisy and their bad characteristics before their appointed time arrives, then Allah will accept their repentance and grant forgiveness for the sins they have committed.
text.97:
This verse explains that the disbelief and hypocrisy of the Bedouin Arabs are more severe than the disbelief and hypocrisy of the cultured Arabs who live settled in cities and villages. The Bedouin Arabs live in the desert, constantly moving, in a barren natural environment, far from the causes of progress, and far from the guidance of the scholars ('ulama), so they rarely receive lessons regarding the Qur'an and Hadith. Therefore, it is not surprising that they do not know the laws that Allah has revealed to His Messenger.

In the explanation of this verse, there is a subtle rebuke for those who live in the city, that they should be more knowledgeable and more advanced than the Bedouins. Because they can associate with and learn from intellectuals, if this is not the case, then they are the same as the Bedouins whose lives are nomadic and far from the guidance of the scholars ('ulama).

Ibn Kathir said that the Bedouin Arabs are rough and harsh, so Allah did not send a Messenger from among them. In this regard, Allah has said:

And We sent not before you (Muhammad) except men to whom We inspired from among the people of cities. (Yusuf/12: 109)

At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that Allah is All-Knowing of the affairs of His servants, whether they are believers or disbelievers, sincere or hypocritical, and He is All-Wise in establishing His sharia and laws, and in giving rewards to His servants, whether in the form of the Garden of Bliss (Jannatun-na'im) or the painful torment of Hell.
text.98:
In this verse, another example of the characteristics of the hypocritical Bedouins is explained, namely those who donate a portion of their wealth for jihad in the path of Allah, but with riya (show-off). They consider the wealth they give, whether due to their obedience or because they are forced to protect themselves and their people from things they do not want, as bringing absolutely no benefit to them in the Hereafter. This is because they do not believe in the Day of Resurrection, where everyone will receive recompense for all the deeds they have done in this world. According to Ibn Zaid, the people referred to in this verse are Bani Â'sad and Bani Gathafan.

In addition to the aforementioned bad characteristics, these hypocrites always hope and wait for calamities to befall the Muslims, weakening their strength. If that happens, the hypocrites will no longer need to donate their wealth for the sake of jihad. In reality, they are always waiting for the polytheists and Jews to defeat the Muslims. However, after their deception yields no results, they await the death of the Messenger of Allah (saw), because they believe that with the death of the Messenger, Islam will disappear and vanish from the face of the earth.

Because of their attitude and views like that, in this verse Allah affirms that they are the ones who will be struck by calamity, while the Muslims will not experience calamity but will receive help from Allah. In addition, the enemies of Islam will meet with failure and be afflicted with torment in this world before receiving a more severe torment in the Hereafter.

At the end of this verse, it is reiterated that Allah is All-Hearing of all the words of His servants, which express the feelings of their hearts, and knows the secrets contained in their hearts, whether it is in the form of faith or disbelief, sincerity or hypocrisy. Allah will reward them for their words and deeds.
text.99:
This verse explains that not all Bedouin Arabs possess the characteristics of disbelief and hypocrisy mentioned above. In fact, some of them are people who believe in Allah and the Last Day, with steadfast faith. They are certain of Allah's omnipotence over all His creation, and they are also certain of the existence of the Last Day, where everyone will receive recompense for all the deeds they have done during their life in this world.

In addition to faith in Allah and the Last Day, they also spend their wealth in the way of Allah. They view what they spend as a way or means to draw closer to Allah and to obtain the prayers of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), because the Messenger of Allah always prayed for goodness for those who like to give charity and spend their wealth in the way of Allah. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) also always sought forgiveness from Allah for them. Prayer to Allah is a good deed that can be done by someone to ask for benefit from Allah for others. For example, the prayer of a righteous child for his parents. According to Mujahid, the people referred to in this verse are Bani Muqrin from the Muzayyanah tribe.

Furthermore, this verse explains that their faith and sincerity, as well as the charity they give with pure intentions, are accepted by Allah as righteous deeds that can bring them closer to Him. Allah will reward them by bestowing upon them a special mercy that He gives to those who are pleasing to Him, in the form of guidance to the straight path that they must take so that they can enter the Garden of Delight (Jannatun-na'im). Here they will live happily under the shade of His mercy and love.

The existence of Bedouin Arabs who believe in Allah and His Messenger because they use their minds and conscience shows how low the position of the disbelievers and hypocrites is who live in cities, always associating with intelligent people and hearing good lessons, yet their hearts remain closed and unwilling to believe.

At the end of this verse, it is affirmed that Allah's mercy and forgiveness are vast for those who are sincere in their deeds. Allah will forgive them for the sins and negligence they have committed. Allah will guide them to good deeds and happiness in this world and the hereafter.
text.100:
In this verse, it is explained that those who were the first to embrace Islam, both from the Muhajirin who migrated from Mecca to Medina, and from the Ansar, the residents of Medina who warmly welcomed the arrival of the Messenger of Allah and the Muhajirin, and likewise the other companions who followed the commands of the Messenger of Allah in the best possible way, these three groups are the believers of the highest rank in the sight of Allah, due to their steadfast faith, and their good and sincere deeds, in accordance with the demands of the Messenger of Allah (saw). Allah is pleased and content with them, and they are content with Allah. Allah has prepared a most noble reward for them, namely the Garden of Paradise (Jannatun-na'im) with rivers flowing beneath it, where they will obtain infinite bliss. They will abide therein forever. That is the greatest victory they will achieve.

What is meant by as-Sabiqunal Awwalun from the Muhajirin are those who migrated from Mecca to Medina before the "Treaty of Hudaibiyah," because before that treaty, the polytheists constantly expelled the Muslims from their homelands, and killed some of them, and hindered anyone who wanted to migrate. There was no other way for a believer to save himself from the evil of the polytheists, except to distance himself from them, or to surrender to their will and desire. Those who chose the first way, namely leaving the city of Mecca and migrating to Medina, were truly believers, there was no hypocrite among them. They left their homeland because of pure faith, sincerity, and the struggle to uphold the religion of Islam.

Also known as as-Sabiqunal Awwalun are those who were the first to embrace Islam and declare their faith to the Prophet Muhammad (saw), from the family were Siti Khadijah, 'Ali bin Abi Thalib, and Zaid bin Haritsah. While from outside the family was Abu Bakar Ash-Shiddiq, the person who accompanied the Messenger of Allah (saw) when he migrated to Medina. In addition, there are also companions who are grouped in as-Sabiqunal Awwalun who have been declared by the Messenger of Allah (saw) as people who are certain to enter Paradise. Among them are Uthman bin Affan, Hamzah, and others.

What is meant by the first group, as-Sabiqunal Awwalun from the Ansar, are the residents of the city of Medina who had declared their pledge of allegiance to the prophethood of Muhammad (saw) at Aqabah, a place in Mina, in the 11th year of the prophethood of Muhammad (saw). At that time they numbered seven people. Then in the following period, namely in the 12th year, a pledge of allegiance also took place in the same place, namely Aqabah, this time followed by seventy men and two women. Their footsteps were followed by others after they were visited by the Messenger of Allah's envoy named Abu Zurarah Mush'ab bin 'Umar bin Hasyim who recited the verses of the Al-Qur'an and taught them religious knowledge. Likewise, those who believed at the time of the arrival of the Messenger of Allah in Medina are included in the group of as-Sabiqunal Awwalun.

The strength and unity of Islam grew and developed after the Messenger of Allah migrated to Medina. At that time, hypocrites emerged who pretended to support the religion of Islam. This is explained in Allah's word that was revealed regarding the circumstances of the Battle of Badr which occurred in the second year of Hijri. Allah's word:

(Remember) when the hypocrites and those in whose hearts was a disease said, "Their religion has deluded those people." (al-Anfal/8: 49)

In the group of hypocrites mentioned in this verse, there is not a single one from the Muhajirin and Ansar who received the title as-Sabiqun al-Awwalun as mentioned above, even though the Ansar were all from the Bani 'Aus and Khazraj.

What is meant by the second group, "allazinat tabuuhum bi ihsan" (those who followed the as-Sabiqunal Awwalun from the Muhajirin and Ansar with excellence) are those who joined in migrating to Medina and struggled to uphold the religion of Islam; or those who proved the unity of deeds and words after receiving guidance and lessons from the as-Sabiqunal Awwalun from the Muhajirin and Ansar, who are leaders worthy of being followed, and made as role models in behavior, actions, speech, and the struggle to uphold the religion of Allah. In short, they are the people who follow the as-Sabiqunal Awwalun in obedience and piety until the Day of Judgment.

As for the third group, namely the hypocrites, they only follow the footsteps of the as-Sabiqunal Awwalun outwardly, not with sincere intentions or only following them in some things, while in other things they deny them.
text.101:
After mentioning the circumstances of the three types of people who truly believe, namely the companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), in this verse Allah mentions the circumstances of the hypocrites, both from the Bedouin tribes and from those residing in the city of Medina, thus revealing two very contrasting things. It is as if Allah is saying, "O you who believe, indeed some of the Bedouins who reside around Medina are very hypocritical. Their hypocrisy and wickedness are extreme. In fact, some of the inhabitants of the city of Medina are also hypocritical. Therefore, be careful of them."

According to al-Bagawi, the "hypocritical Bedouin people who live around the city of Medina" are those from Bani Muzainah, Bani Juhainah, Bani Asyja, Bani Aslam, and Bani Gifar. While the "hypocritical people from among the inhabitants of the city of Medina itself" are the hypocrites from Bani Aus and Khazraj. These people are extremely excessive and very skilled at concealing their hypocrisy, making it difficult for the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims in general to know them. They cannot be expected to return to true faith. Nevertheless, Allah always knows their hypocrisy, and He will inflict punishment upon them twice: in this world in the form of misery and inner suffering, as well as the agony of death. In the Hereafter, they will be thrown into a severe punishment, in the lowest level of Hell, Jahannam.

From the explanation above, it can be concluded that the hypocrites are divided into two groups. First, those whose hypocrisy can be known from their attitudes, actions, and words. Second, those who are very skilled at concealing their hypocrisy, making it difficult to know.
text.102:
This verse explains the fourth group, which does not include the hypocrites, nor *as-Sabiqunal Awwalun* (the first to embrace Islam), and neither does it include the group of "those who follow the footsteps of *as-Sabiqunal Awwalun* well." These are sinful believers who honestly acknowledge their sins. They have mixed good deeds with bad deeds, so their actions are neither entirely good nor entirely bad.

Thus, they are not truly righteous people, nor are they included in the group of the wicked or hypocrites, because in reality they like to do good but often do bad.

Among their bad deeds was not participating in the Battle of Tabuk with the other Muslims, even though they had no *uzur* (valid excuse) or justified reason, because they were not weak or sick; and they did not offer false excuses like the hypocrites did; and they did not ask for permission like those who were doubtful. However, they realized their mistake when they did not participate in the war and their hearts feared Allah. Thus, on the one hand, they did not want to fulfill their obligation, and on the other hand, they realized their mistake because they feared Allah.

Furthermore, this verse explains that this group still has hope that their repentance will be accepted by Allah. Their repentance is the key to obtaining His forgiveness and mercy. True repentance can only be achieved when a person has understood the evil of sin and its consequences, so that fear arises when remembering Allah's wrath and His punishment. Then arises the desire to cleanse oneself from all things that cause sin, in addition to a strong intention and determination not to repeat the act, and striving hard to do various good deeds to erase sins from prohibited acts that have been committed, and have bad consequences for society and oneself.

At the end of this verse, the reason why there is still hope for sinners that their repentance will be accepted by Allah is explained, because indeed Allah is the Most Forgiving to His servants who want to repent sincerely; and Allah is the Most Merciful to His servants who want to do good.

According to one narration, this verse was revealed in connection with an event that happened to six Muslims who deliberately failed to participate in the Battle of Tabuk. They were Abu Lubabah, Aus bin sa'labah, Wadi'ah bin hadzdzam, Ka'ab bin Malik, Murarah bin Rabi, and Hilal bin Umayyah. After realizing their mistake for not participating in the war, three of them, namely Abu Lubabah, Aus and sa'labah, came to the mosque bringing their possessions, then they tied themselves to the pillars of the mosque, and were determined that only the Messenger of Allah would release them from those bonds. They intended to hand over the possessions to the Messenger of Allah to be distributed to those who were entitled to receive them as charity to atone for their mistakes. After this was conveyed to the Messenger of Allah *saw*, he said, "I will not release them from those bonds until a decree comes from Allah." Then this verse was revealed. The Messenger of Allah then opened the ropes that bound them to the pillars.

Ibn Kathir argues, "Although this verse was revealed about certain people, its content still applies generally, encompassing all sinners who mix good and bad deeds and then realize their mistakes, then they repent to Allah in the best possible way."
text.103:
Allah's command at the beginning of this verse is addressed to His Messenger, so that the Messenger of Allah, as a leader, takes a portion of their wealth as charity or zakat. This is to be proof of the truthfulness of their repentance, because the charity or zakat will cleanse them from the sins arising from their absence from battle and to purify them from the characteristic of "love of wealth" that drove them to abstain from that battle. In addition, the charity or zakat will also cleanse them from all the bad traits that arise from wealth, such as stinginess, greed, and so on. Therefore, the Messenger sent his companions to collect zakat from the Muslims.

Besides that, it can be said that fulfilling zakat means purifying the remaining wealth, because in a person's wealth there is the right of others, namely those who have been determined by the Islamic religion as people who are entitled to receive zakat. As long as the zakat has not been paid by the owner of the wealth, then for that long the wealth remains mixed with the rights of others, which is forbidden to consume. However, if he takes out zakat from his wealth, then the wealth becomes clean from the rights of others. The person who gives zakat is freed from the characteristics of stinginess and greed. Fulfilling zakat will cause blessings on the remaining wealth, so that it grows and multiplies. Conversely, if zakat is not given, then a person's wealth will not receive blessings.

It should be noted that although Allah's command in this verse is outwardly addressed to His Messenger, and the revelation of this verse concerns the event of Abu Lubabah and his companions, the law also applies to all leaders or rulers in every Muslim society, to carry out Allah's command in this matter of zakat, namely to collect the zakat from Muslims who are obligated to pay zakat, and then distribute the zakat to those who are entitled to receive it. Thus, zakat will be able to fulfill its function as an effective means of building social welfare.

Furthermore, in this verse Allah commands His Messenger, and also every leader and ruler in society, that after collecting and distributing zakat, they should pray to Allah for the safety and happiness of the zakat payers. The prayer will calm their souls, and will soothe their hearts, and create confidence in their hearts that Allah has truly accepted their repentance.

May Allah reward you for what you give, and bless what you leave behind.

At the end of this verse it is explained that Allah is All-Hearing of every word of His servant who repents, Allah is All-Knowing of all that is stored in the depths of His servant's heart, such as the feelings of regret and anxiety that arise from the awareness of the mistakes that have been made.
text.104:
With this verse, Allah encourages His servants who have realized their mistakes to repent and give charity, in order to erase their sins. Furthermore, this verse also affirms that whoever repents to Allah, He will accept their repentance; and whoever gives charity sincerely, Allah will accept that charity as a righteous deed and will reward them with blessings.

Although this verse is in the form of a question, the Arabs were accustomed to presenting sentences in the form of questions to establish and emphasize a meaning, namely the certainty that Allah will truly accept the repentance of those who are aware of their sins, and will also accept the charity they give because they solely seek Allah's pleasure, to erase the sins they have already committed.

This verse is also a strong rebuke against those who err but do not acknowledge their mistakes, do not want to repent, and do not want to do good deeds and righteous acts to erase the sins they have committed.

At the end of this verse, it is affirmed that Allah is the Acceptor of Repentance and the Most Merciful towards His servants. Therefore, Allah will always accept the repentance of His servants, because this attribute is a permanent attribute for Him, and becomes a *Sunnah* that applies forever. He always has mercy on His servants so that He will forgive their sins, and accept the righteous deeds they do, and give a fitting reward.
text.105:
In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger to say to the Muslims who wish to repent and purify themselves from sins by giving charity, paying zakat, and performing as many good deeds as possible. In addition, Allah also commands His Messenger to convey to his ummah that if they have performed these good deeds, then Allah, His Messenger, and other believers will see and evaluate these deeds. Finally, they will be returned to the afterlife, and they will be given rewards for the deeds they performed during their life in the world. They are encouraged not to be satisfied with merely repenting, paying zakat, giving charity, and praying, but they must do all that is commanded of them. Allah will see the deeds they do, so that they get closer to Him. The Messenger of Allah and the Muslims will see these good deeds, so that they too will follow and emulate them. And Allah gives manifold rewards to those who become role models, without diminishing the rewards of those who emulate them.

As is known, Muslims will be witnesses before Allah on the Day of Judgment regarding the faith and deeds of fellow Muslims. Testimony based on one's own eyesight is stronger and more reliable. Therefore, Muslims who see the good deeds performed by those who are aware and repent to Allah will certainly be strong witnesses on the Day of Judgment about the truth of their faith, repentance, and good deeds.

This verse also contains a stern warning to those who violate religious commands, that their deeds will also be shown to the Messenger and other Muslims on the Day of Judgment. Thus, their shame will be revealed, because it will be proven that their good deeds are very few, and conversely, the sins of the evils they commit are more numerous. Even in this world, the lack of their good deeds and the abundance of evil they commit will be shown. In a narration (riwayat) it is mentioned that the deeds of the living are shown to the dead, namely from among family members and relatives who are in the realm of Barzakh.

With a person's death, he is returned to the afterlife. There, Allah will inform each person about the results of the actions they have done while they were in the world by giving rewards for their deeds. Good is rewarded with good, and evil is rewarded with torment and punishment.
text.106:
Three people did not go to the battlefield with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him): Murarah bin Rabi', Ka'ab bin Malik, and Hilal bin Umayyah. In their hearts, they had the desire to join, but they were unable to do so, and their absence was not due to hypocrisy. After the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) returned from the battlefield, they said to him, "We had no obstacles; our absence was purely a mistake." And they did not offer excuses for that mistake. They did not do as Abu Lubabah and his companions had done.

Because of Allah's affirmation in this verse that their repentance was deferred, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) forbade the other Muslims from associating and sitting with them. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) also ordered the three of them to stay away from their wives and instructed the wives to return to their families until the revelation of Allah's word confirming the acceptance of their repentance, as mentioned above.

This deferment contained two possibilities: whether Allah would punish them or whether He would accept their repentance if they repented. Thus, neither they nor others knew what would happen to them. Would their repentance be of any use, so that Allah would accept their repentance as happened to their companions who had repented and acknowledged their mistakes? Or would Allah inflict punishment upon them in this world and the hereafter, as He had decreed for those who did not participate in the war because of their hypocrisy?

This deferment contained wisdom, so that feelings of anxiety and sadness would arise in their hearts, and then they would repent sincerely. In addition, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and the other Muslims were ordered to avoid and isolate them, as a lesson to them that anyone who only prioritizes personal pleasure and does not care about the common good, as well as obedience to Allah and His Messenger, deserves to be taught a lesson.

At the end of this verse, it is affirmed that Allah is All-Knowing of what can improve the condition of His servants. He educates His servants on how to cleanse themselves from all evil, both individually and collectively. Allah is All-Wise in establishing His clear and beneficial laws for their improvement and self-enhancement, if they truly obey the regulations and laws that He has established. One of Allah's wisdoms is the deferment of the affirmation of whether their repentance is accepted or not. If this is read or heard repeatedly by other believers, it will undoubtedly instill fear in their hearts of doing such a thing. Of course, this is a kind of good education and lesson for the entire ummah, especially for those who commit the same mistake.
text.107:
In this verse, Allah explains the intentions behind their establishing the mosque, which are:

1. To harm the believers who regularly worship at the Quba Mosque, the mosque built by the Prophet Muhammad (saw) when he first migrated from Mecca, before reaching Medina.

2. As a facility for carrying out various acts as a manifestation of disbelief. The hypocrites secretly abandoned prayer in the building they erected, so that the Muslims could not know because they no longer performed worship together at the Quba Mosque. In addition, the existence of the building could also be a place to hold free discussions in plotting against the Prophet (saw).

3. To create division among the Muslims residing in that area. Because they not only prayed at the Quba Mosque, but they also met and got to know each other, worked together, and made agreements on various issues. This is the most important purpose of a mosque in the social sphere. Therefore, it is a necessity for Muslims residing in a particular area to all perform Friday prayers in one mosque as long as it is possible.

From this, it can be understood that building a new mosque can be seen as a good deed accepted by Allah, if it is truly needed, for example, because the old mosque is damaged, or can no longer accommodate the growing number of Muslims, and not built for the purpose of dividing the Muslims. Therefore, the construction of mosques that are located close to each other, and are only driven by feelings of *riya* (showing off) and personal or group pride, is not justified by religion.

4. To become a refuge for those who habitually fight against the religion of Allah, so that when they come to that place, they already have a safe haven, obtain allies and supporters to fight together against the Prophet (saw) and the Muslims. These are the polytheists and hypocrites who deliberately built the building as their defense to divide and fight against the Muslims.

In this verse, it is further explained that the hypocrites swore to strengthen their words, that the building was built solely to obtain goodness, for example, to make it easier for the weak, to perform Friday prayers near their homes, and so on. However, the oath was only to cover up the evil intentions stored in their hearts.

At the end of the verse, Allah affirms that He witnesses that they are truly liars.
text.108:
Because of the evil intentions of the hypocrites in establishing that building, Allah forbade His Messenger forever from praying in that place, because if the Messenger of Allah prayed there with them, it would mean he was approving of their building of it.

Furthermore, Allah affirms to His Messenger that a mosque built from the outset on the basis of piety (taqwa) towards Allah is better to be used as a place of worship together with his people, to unite all Muslims in everything that pleases Him, namely, to get to know each other and to jointly do good deeds and piety.

The mosque that was first established on the basis of piety, mentioned in this verse, is "Masjid Quba" or "Masjid an-Nabi" (the Prophet's Mosque) in the city of Medina, because both mosques were built by the Prophet and the Muslims on the basis of piety.

Furthermore, in this verse, Allah explains the reason why that mosque is more superior to other mosques that were deliberately built not on the basis of piety, because in that mosque there are people who like to purify themselves from all sins. This means that they enliven the mosque by establishing prayer and remembering and glorifying Allah. Through these acts of worship, they want to purify themselves from all the sins that cling to them, just as those who shirked from battle then realized their mistakes, then tried to purify themselves from those sins by repenting, giving charity, and increasing other good deeds. Performing the prayer means purifying oneself outwardly and inwardly because performing the prayer requires the purity of the body, clothing, and place, as well as the presence of the heart and mind directed solely to Allah.

At the end of this verse, it is affirmed that Allah loves those who greatly maintain the cleanliness of their souls and bodies, because they consider that human perfection lies in inner and outer purity. Therefore, they greatly despise outward filth, such as dirt on the body, clothing, and place, as well as inner filth that arises from continuous acts of disobedience, and bad character, such as riya (showing off) in deeds, or stinginess in donating wealth to obtain Allah's pleasure. Allah's love for those who like to purify themselves is one of His attributes of perfection; He loves goodness, perfection, purity, and truth. Conversely, He hates attributes that are contrary to those attributes.
text.109:
This verse begins with a question, Allah showing a clear difference between those who establish mosques on the basis of piety and the desire to achieve His pleasure, and those who establish mosques with evil intentions, so that the construction of the mosque does not bring rewards but instead adds to the accumulation of their sins. The latter are likened to those who build a building on the edge of a collapsing cliff, so that they eventually fall together with the mosque they built into the Hell of Jahannam.

From this it can be understood that those who establish mosques on the basis of piety and the desire to achieve Allah's pleasure are like those who build a strong building on strong ground, resistant to wind and storms, not decaying from rain, and not fading from heat. It provides protection, security, peace, and happiness to those who are inside it.

In other words, the Prophet Muhammad (saw) and the Muslims who truly believe in Allah always base all their actions on piety and His pleasure. They are better than the hypocrites who do their deeds only based on bad intentions, which increase disbelief and hypocrisy, as well as the intention to divide the Muslim community. In this world they are blameworthy, while in the Hereafter they will be afflicted with Allah's torment and wrath.

After explaining the good fortune of the believers and the bad fate of the unjust hypocrites, at the end of the verse Allah affirms that He will not give guidance to the unjust people. This means that the unjust will never obtain guidance towards goodness and good fortune. Therefore, every step, behavior, and action of theirs will always experience failure and disaster, both in this world and in the Hereafter.
text.110:
In this verse, Allah explains that the mosque established by the hypocrites constantly caused doubt in their hearts regarding religion. This is because, after the building was erected, they used it to commit evil deeds, including making evil plans and conspiracies directed at the Messenger of Allah (saw) and the Muslims. This demonstrates their hypocrisy and disbelief. After the Messenger of Allah sent some companions to demolish the building, the hypocrites became even more doubtful about their fate, and felt fear and anxiety. This state only ended after their hearts were as if shattered into pieces, so that they could no longer know the truth. This means that throughout their lives, their hearts were constantly in doubt and uncertainty. The collapse of their mosque building also caused the collapse of their life's foundation, so that anxiety, fear, and doubt constantly enveloped their hearts until they died and their bodies were shattered into pieces. Or, after they repented and regretted all the sins and mistakes they had committed.

At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that Allah is All-Knowing of His servants' actions and All-Wise in all His actions. One of His wisdoms is His notification to the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims about the evil of the hypocrites, so that from their characteristics and evil deeds, they could know who they were and the consequences of their evil could be avoided.
text.111:
This verse explains that Allah buys the lives and possessions of the believers, which He pays for with Paradise. This means that Allah rewards all the struggles and sacrifices that the believers have made, whether in the form of their lives and bodies or their wealth, with the best possible reward, namely the pleasure and happiness in Paradise in the future. This is a very beautiful expression to arouse enthusiasm for mankind to strive in the path of Allah (jihad), because it describes a very profitable buying and selling transaction for humans. The sacrifices they have made in the form of wealth and lives will be exchanged for something very valuable, which has never been seen by human eyes, never been heard by ears, and whose value is far higher than material possessions and anything that has been sacrificed. In addition, this buying and selling that takes place between Allah and the Muslims will never be canceled. Unlike buying and selling transactions that occur between humans, which can sometimes be canceled. Moreover, buying and selling between humans only involves the exchange of goods and money of equal value. While the reward that Allah gives to His believing servants is far higher in value than the sacrifices that have been made or the struggles that have been carried out.

The manifold rewards that Allah bestows upon His servants are solely due to His love and are an honor to His believing servants, because in essence, human beings belong to Him, because He is the Creator; and their possessions also belong to Him, because He is the One who bestows them upon them. Nevertheless, when humans strive in the path of Allah (jihad) by sacrificing their possessions and lives, Allah still gives rewards that are manifold in value, even though Allah Himself does not actually need their possessions and lives.

Furthermore, in this verse, Allah explains how to surrender the lives and possessions that will be bought by Allah with Paradise, namely by fighting in the way of Allah to defend truth and justice. This is what will lead them to His pleasure; sometimes they can eradicate the enemies of Allah who always hinder the path of Islamic da'wah, sometimes they fall in battle, as martyrs in defending the religion of Allah. However, there is no difference between the two in receiving rewards and recompense from Allah.

Allah affirms that His promise to give rewards will be fulfilled, and has even been established in such a way in the Torah, the Gospel, and the Al-Qur'an. This last holy book cannot be erased by anyone, because Allah has guaranteed the safety of the Al-Qur'an from ignorant hands.

Furthermore, Allah affirms that there is no one greater than Allah in fulfilling promises, because He is All-Powerful to fulfill His promises, and never forgets or doubts His servants. Therefore, Allah will give good news that they will surely obtain from the buying and selling of their wealth and lives with Allah.

At the end of this verse, Allah again provides affirmation that the fortune they will obtain is truly a great fortune, nothing exceeds it. While the fortune they have obtained previously in the form of victory over the enemies of Islam, as well as leadership, power and kingdom, is only a fortune that is a way to uphold justice and truth.
text.112:
In this verse, several characteristics of the believers who have reached the peak of faith are mentioned, those who have sacrificed their wealth and lives in striving to uphold and establish the religion of Allah.

These characteristics are:

1. They are those who repent, returning to Allah by abandoning every action that would distance them from His pleasure. Thus, the repentance of those who were once disbelievers is their return to the path of Allah and the implementation of His Sharia.

In this regard, Allah has said:

"But if they repent, establish prayer, and give zakah, then they are your brothers in religion." (at-Taubah/9: 11)

While the repentance of those who were once hypocrites is by abandoning their hypocrisy. The repentance of the disobedient is by abandoning their disobedience, regretting what they have done, and resolving not to repeat the act, as was the repentance of some believers (Abu Lubabah and his companions) who had failed to join the Battle of Tabuk. As for the repentance of those who have been negligent in doing good, it is by doing other good deeds in greater quantity, while the repentance of those who have been negligent in remembering Allah is by remembering and being grateful more after realizing their negligence.

2. Believers who reach the peak of faith have the characteristic of worshiping Allah alone sincerely, without *riya* (showing off) or *shirk* (associating partners with Allah). All their worship, prayers, and hopes are directed to Allah alone. They avoid all actions intended to draw closer to other than Allah or to seek help from other than Allah, whether for worldly or otherworldly interests.

3. Believers are described as those who constantly offer praise to Allah, both in times of joy and in times of sorrow.

In this regard, 'Aisha r.a. explained that the Prophet Muhammad saw, whenever he found something pleasing, he would say words of praise that read:

"All praise is due to Allah, by whose grace all good things are perfected." (Narrated by Ibn Majah and al-Hakim)

And when he faced something he did not want, he would say words of praise that read:

"All praise is due to Allah in all circumstances." (Narrated by Abu Dawud, at-Tirmidzi, and others)

4. Believers who reach the peak of perfection also have the characteristic of being fond of traveling for good and righteous purposes, for example, traveling to seek knowledge, both religious knowledge and knowledge for worldly progress, or for something beneficial to the progress and welfare of the nation and homeland. Or traveling to see and observe the conditions of other nations and countries, so that from all of that, useful lessons can be learned, and increase our faith and worship to Allah, the Creator of the universe. In the Al-Qur'an, there are many words of Allah that encourage humans to travel on this earth, to gain experience and lessons, which will strengthen their faith. Among them is the word of Allah:

"Say, "Travel through the land and observe how was the end of those who denied."" (al-An'am/6: 11)

And His word in another verse:

"Have they not considered how many generations We destroyed before them which We had established upon the earth as We have not established you? (al-An'am/6: 6)

There are many other verses that are in line with the verses above that tell humans to pay more attention to God's creatures in this world. The farther you walk, the more you see, and it gives you a lot of knowledge, experience, and lessons, which ultimately increase your faith and piety to Allah.

5. Another characteristic possessed by true believers is that they always perform *ruku* (bowing) and *sujud* (prostration) to Allah, namely establishing prayer. Allah deliberately mentions the issue of *ruku* and *sujud* in this verse, because these two things show the nature of submission, humility, and self-abasement to Allah, and also to illustrate that the work of prayer is never separated from *ruku'* and *sujud*.

6. Two other characteristics of true believers are that they like to invite others to do good, and prevent them from evil deeds, by inviting them to faith and doing deeds that are the fruit of that faith, namely things that are good and beneficial for personal life and community life.

7. The last characteristic mentioned in this verse is that they are people who always guard themselves from exceeding the limits and provisions that Allah has set, such as His Sharia and laws, which must be followed by believers for their happiness in this world and the hereafter, and what they must avoid, because of the dangers that can be caused. Likewise, in these laws and Sharia, it has also been explained what must be done by Muslims and their leaders, both for the personal interests of Muslims, and for the glory of the Islamic community in general.
text.113:
In this verse, it is explained that it is not appropriate for the Prophet and the believers to petition Allah to grant forgiveness to polytheists, even if they are relatives of the Prophet or relatives of the believers. Especially if the Prophet and the believers have obtained clear evidence that those for whom forgiveness is sought are destined for Hell, because their actions and behavior have shown their denial of Allah.

In verse 80 of Surah at-Taubah, Allah has also explained that He will not grant forgiveness to the hypocrites, because they have disbelieved in Allah and His Messenger, so it is all the same whether the Messenger of Allah asks for forgiveness for them or not. In verses 48 and 116 of Surah an-Nisa, Allah has also affirmed that He will not grant forgiveness to anyone who commits shirk, which is associating partners with Allah.

Those who associate partners with Allah, even if they claim to believe and worship Allah, also worship others besides Allah. This shows that they do not believe in the perfection and power of Allah. Therefore, in another verse, Allah affirms that shirk is a great injustice and an unforgivable sin. That is why Luqman al-Hakim gave his son the lesson not to associate partners with Allah. He said:

"O my son! Join not in worship others with Allah. Verily! Joining others in worship with Allah is a great Zulm (wrong) indeed." (Luqman/31: 13)
