In the above verse (113), there is an indication that praying for those who have died in disbelief, so that they may obtain forgiveness and the mercy of Allah, is forbidden. This prohibition includes all kinds and ways of praying, both the prayers that are usually performed after prayer and the prayers that are recited in certain ceremonies.

It is narrated by Imam Ahmad, Imam Muslim, and Abu Daud from Abu Hurairah that the Messenger of Allah (saw) once visited the grave of his mother, then he cried, causing the people around him to cry as well. Then he said, "I asked Allah for permission to ask for forgiveness for my mother, but Allah did not grant permission, and I asked for permission to visit my mother's grave, so Allah granted permission. Therefore, you may visit graves because it will remind you of death."

With the prohibition of Allah in this verse to the Prophet and the believers from asking for forgiveness for the polytheists, it can be concluded that true prophethood and faith will not allow a person to offer prayers to Allah to forgive the polytheists in any situation, even if they are beloved relatives. This is because for the Prophet and the believers it is clear enough from various evidence and realities that the polytheists have died in disbelief, thus they are destined for Hell, so it is not appropriate to ask for forgiveness from Allah, because their actions are not pleasing to Him.
text.114:
From the explanations contained in the verses above, a question might arise in our minds: why did Allah forbid the Prophet Muhammad saw and the Muslims from seeking forgiveness for those who died in polytheism and disbelief, even if they were relatives and their own parents, whereas the Prophet Ibrahim once sought forgiveness for his father, who was also a polytheist who died in polytheism and disbelief?

In this verse, Allah provides His answer: it is true that the Prophet Ibrahim once sought forgiveness from Allah for his father named Azar, by uttering the following prayer:

"And forgive my father, indeed, he has been of those astray." (ash-Syuara'/26: 86)

However, the Prophet Ibrahim did so because he had promised his father to pray for him, hoping that Allah would grant him guidance to believe, and give him guidance to the right path that he had laid out. His promise indicated that the Prophet Ibrahim already believed that his duty was only to pray to Allah, while he himself had no authority to give guidance or salvation, let alone forgive his sins.

Thus, Ibrahim fulfilled his promise, but only as a fulfillment of a promise. This is also mentioned by Allah in His word:

"And [of] Abraham, who fulfilled [his obligations]?" (an-Najm/53: 37)

In the next verse, Allah explains that even though Ibrahim had sought forgiveness for his father to fulfill his promise, after it became clear to him that his father truly opposed Allah in polytheism, Ibrahim no longer prayed for his father after his death. The Prophet Ibrahim prayed for his father when his father was still alive, hoping that his father would receive guidance and taufik from Allah, abandon his polytheism and repent to Allah. Such a prayer is not forbidden.

The faith of a person in Allah and the Last Day will not allow him to love those who oppose Allah and His Messenger. This has been affirmed by Allah in His word in other verses:

"You will not find a people who believe in Allah and the Last Day having affection for those who oppose Allah and His Messenger, even if they were their fathers or their sons or their brothers or their kindred." (al-Mujadalah/58: 22)

During his father's lifetime, the Prophet Ibrahim already knew about his behavior that was not pleasing to Allah, so he himself was once threatened with harsh words, which are mentioned in the following verse:

"[His father] said, "Have you no desire for my gods, O Abraham? If you do not desist, I will surely stone you, so avoid me for a prolonged time." (Maryam/19: 46)

Nevertheless, Ibrahim also promised his father to pray to Allah for forgiveness, mercy, and guidance. However, after his father died, it became clear to Ibrahim that his father truly opposed Allah during his lifetime. So Ibrahim no longer prayed for him. What was the reason for this?

Then, at the end of this verse, Allah explains the answer to this question, namely: because Ibrahim was a man who greatly feared Allah, and was obedient and submissive to Him, he was also known as a compassionate person, and steadfast in all matters.

That is why the Prophet Ibrahim immediately stopped praying for his father, after knowing that he was truly a polytheist, who had firmly planted in his heart the belief in shirk and hostility towards Allah. The Prophet Ibrahim was gentle-hearted, he greatly regretted the attitude of the polytheists among his people, including his own father.
text.115:
In this verse, Allah affirms that if a people have truly been guided, and their hearts have been opened to accept the religion of Islam, then He will never consider them to be misguided, and then treat them the same as those who are truly misguided, who deserve to be blamed and punished. Allah will not do so if they only commit one mistake, whether in speech or in action, caused by an error in their *ijtihad*. Allah will not blame and punish them for such mistakes until they truly understand the teachings of religion, both in the form of prohibitions that they must avoid, and commands that must be carried out.

At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that Allah is All-Knowing of everything, including the needs of mankind for information and explanation. Therefore, Allah has explained the important issues in religion with definitive explanations in His word, so that Muslims will be able to reach the truth in their *ijtihad* and will not be tempted by their desires.

That is why Allah did not blame the Prophet Ibrahim when he asked forgiveness for his father because it was done before he received clear evidence and explanation about his father's condition. After he received clear evidence and proof, he immediately stopped his prayer.

Likewise, Allah will not inflict punishment on the Prophet Muhammad (saw) and the believers who have asked forgiveness from Allah for their parents and relatives who died in disbelief, if it was done before obtaining a clear explanation regarding Allah's provisions in this matter.
text.116:
Allah explains that He is the One who possesses power, both in the heavens and on earth. He is the One who controls everything in this universe. He is also the One who causes His servants to die when their appointed time arrives. And His Sunnah is what prevails in this universe. There is no one who manages and controls the interests of the believers, and there is no one who will help them against their enemies, except Allah SWT.

Therefore, the believers must not deviate from Allah's decrees, especially regarding His prohibition against seeking forgiveness for polytheists, even if they are relatives who deserve to be cared for and helped. Likewise, in other provisions, whether in the form of prohibitions or His commands.
text.117:
This verse is a continuation of the previous verses, concerning the issue of repentance from those who shirked the Battle of Tabuk. It is a common practice in the Qur'an to pause one discussion, then introduce another, but then return to discussing the original issue. This kind of approach provides a more solid understanding and a strong impression in the hearts and minds of those who hear or read it, and it is not boring. In addition, there is a connection with the prohibition against seeking forgiveness for polytheists, mentioned in the previous verse, because in both of these issues there are errors that need to be atoned for through repentance, and correcting errors that need to be asked for forgiveness from Allah.

In this verse, Allah affirms that He has accepted the repentance of the Prophet Muhammad saw and the Muhajirin and Ansar and other believers, who followed the Prophet in difficult times, namely during the Battle of Tabuk, because the Battle of Tabuk occurred in a time of hardship. Hardship of food, because it was a time of famine, so that one or two people ate a single date. Hardship of water, so that some slaughtered their camels in order to take water from their stomachs to drink, even though they desperately needed the camels for transportation from one place to another, so that one camel was used for the needs of ten people. Added to this was the extremely hot weather at that time (when the Battle of Tabuk took place). The acceptance of repentance occurred after the hearts of a group of the Ansar and Muhajirin had almost turned away, so they went to war with reluctance and heaviness, and some even deliberately shirked the war. But then Allah accepted their repentance after they realized their mistakes.

At the end of this verse, it is affirmed that Allah is Most Compassionate and Most Merciful to the Prophet and his followers. Therefore, He always accepts the repentance of those who truly repent to Him.

According to the interpretation of Ibn 'Abbas, what is meant by Allah accepting the repentance of the Prophet is the repentance that the Prophet made for his mistake in allowing some people not to participate in the war, even though they did not have justifiable excuses. What is meant by the acceptance of the repentance of the Muhajirin and Ansar is the repentance they made for their mistakes when they felt reluctant to go to the battlefield, even though they were considered the strongest in faith. Some of them had the mistake of liking to listen to the conversations of the hypocrites, even though the conversations were intended to create fitnah among the Muslims.
text.118:
In this verse, the circumstances of three individuals among the believers who failed to participate in the Battle of Tabuk are revealed again: Ka'ab bin Malik, Hilal bin Umayyah, and Murarah bin Rabi. Initially, they intentionally did not join the Prophet Muhammad (saw) in the battle, but later they experienced psychological pressure, and the world felt constricted to them because other believers viewed them as dishonorable. They felt certain that only Allah is the refuge from all His punishments. After awareness and regret came, they repented to Allah. Allah accepted that repentance, so that they would remain in awareness, returning to the religion of Allah with the guidance of His Messenger, after having already committed a violation against His command.

At the end of this verse, it is reaffirmed that Allah is the Most Accepting of Repentance and the Most Merciful to His servants. He always accepts the repentance of His servants who truly repent to Him and forgives sins and bestows His mercy and blessings upon them, even though they have already committed errors that would entitle them to punishment and torment.
text.119:
Allah shows His call and gives guidance to those who believe in Him and His Messenger, so that they remain in piety and hope for His pleasure, by fulfilling all the obligations He has established, and avoiding all the prohibitions He has determined, and should always be with those who are true and honest, following their piety, truth, and honesty. And do not join the hypocrites, who always cover up their hypocrisy with false words and deeds, coupled with false oaths and untrue reasons.

Al-Baihaqi narrated a hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), that he said:

Verily, truthfulness leads to righteousness, and righteousness leads to Paradise. Indeed, a person will be truthful until he is written with Allah as being truthful. And verily, falsehood leads to wickedness, and wickedness leads to Hellfire. Indeed, a person will tell lies until he is written with Allah as a liar. (Hadith Muttafaq 'Alaih)

Lying is always forbidden except when necessary, as a trick in warfare, or to reconcile between disputing parties, or a man's lie to his wife that is intended to please her, for example in praising her beauty, but not lying in matters of finance and the interests of household life or others. In this regard, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said:

Every lie committed by a person is always written as his sin except for a person who lies as a trick in warfare, or a lie to reconcile two people who are in dispute, or a lie that a person tells his wife with the intention of pleasing her. (Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaibah and Ahmad, from Asma bint Yazid)
text.120:
Allah explains that the Muslims residing in the city of Medina, and the Bedouin Muslims living around the city of Medina, should accompany the Messenger of Allah (saw) to the battlefield and it is not fitting for them to not love the Messenger of Allah (saw) by loving themselves more. If they do not join the battlefield and only stay at home, this means they are unwilling to endure various sufferings to defend the religion of Allah, they do not feel thirst, fatigue, and hunger, nor do they tread on territory defended by the disbelievers, nor do they inflict any disaster upon the enemy as felt and carried out by those who participate in the war. Whereas if they experience and carry out these things, it will surely be written for them in the sight of Allah as righteous deeds each time they experience and carry them out, and they will be given a great reward as is done for those who participate in the war with the Messenger of Allah. Every good deed done by the believers, whether in the form of physical or spiritual sacrifice, will not be wasted by Allah, especially good deeds to defend His religion.

Those who stay at home without a reason justified by Allah are indeed people who prioritize themselves, unwilling to make sacrifices and endure suffering for the common good and to defend the religion of Allah. Whereas the pleasures they obtain in their households are solely a gift and mercy from Allah.

Loyalty and obedience to the Messenger of Allah must be in all situations and circumstances, both in times of joy and sorrow, requiring sacrifice over personal pleasure, the enjoyment of life, possessions, and body and soul. Therefore, when a danger arises that threatens the common good, the honor of the nation and religion, then every believer must rise up to fight together, without calculating profit and loss for themselves. This is more noble than living in luxury, but losing one's self-respect, religion, nation, and homeland.

Allah does not waste every good deed and sacrifice given by every believer. A great reward is prepared by Him for the believers who have fought with the Messenger of Allah, and furthermore, for the believers who strive in the way of Allah, until the Day of Judgment. The recompense for every good deed is good in return, this is the decree from Allah.
text.121:
Allah explains that those who stay at home and do not go to the battlefield with the Messenger of Allah, certainly do not contribute to the struggle and do not experience the hardship of traversing valleys and deserts. It is different with those who participate in war. Those who do and experience such things will surely be written down with Allah as righteous deeds, because Allah will give them a reward that is far higher in value than what they have contributed and what they have done.

Those who participate in war and contribute their wealth for the struggle in the way of Allah, mean they have made two kinds of noble sacrifices, namely the sacrifice of wealth, and the sacrifice of body and soul. The most noble sacrifice, of course, deserves to be given the most noble reward as well, even the reward is higher than the sacrifice that has been given. Regarding this matter, there is a provision in the Islamic religion, as Allah says:

"Whoever comes [on the Day of Judgement] with a good deed will have ten times the like thereof [to his credit]." (al-An'am/6: 160)

It should be remembered that the great reward is not only given by Allah to the believers who sacrifice their wealth and body and soul in war, but also to the believers who do good deeds in other fields. However, the sacrifice given in *jihad* on the battlefield to defend religion is more noble than the sacrifice for other interests. So that a small amount of wealth sacrificed for the needs of *jihad* is equal in value to a large amount of wealth sacrificed for other virtues. A small amount of suffering suffered in *jihad* is equal in value to the great suffering experienced in other good deeds.
text.122:
In this verse, Allah explains that not all believers must go to the battlefield if the war can be carried out by only some Muslims. But there must be a division of labor in society, some going to the battlefield, and others pursuing knowledge and deepening their understanding of Islam, so that religious teachings can be taught evenly, and da'wah can be carried out in a more effective and beneficial way so that the intelligence of the Muslim community can be improved.

War aims to defeat the enemies of Islam and secure the path of Islamic da'wah. Meanwhile, seeking knowledge and deepening religious knowledge aims to educate the ummah and develop Islam, so that it can be disseminated and understood by all levels of society.

Thus, this verse has a close relationship with the previous verses, because they both explain the law of jihad, but in different fields and ways.

The task of the ulama in Islam is to study their religion, practice it well, and then convey that religious knowledge to those who do not yet know it. These tasks are the tasks of the ummah and every individual Muslim, according to their respective abilities and knowledge, because the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said:

Convey from me, even if it is only one verse of the Qur'an. (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

However, not every Muslim has the opportunity to seek and deepen knowledge and deepen religious knowledge, because they are busy with tasks on the battlefield, in the fields, in factories, in shops, and so on. Therefore, there must be some of the Muslim community who use their time and energy to seek knowledge and deepen religious knowledge, so that after they finish and return to society, they can spread that knowledge, and carry out Islamic da'wah in good ways and methods so as to achieve better results.

If the Muslim community has understood the teachings of their religion, and has understood the laws of halal and haram, as well as religious commands and prohibitions, then they will be better able to protect themselves from error and disobedience, be able to carry out religious commands well and be able to avoid His prohibitions. Thus, the Muslim community becomes a good community, prosperous in this world and the hereafter.

In addition, it should be remembered that if the Muslim community faces a war that requires a large number of people, then in this case the entire Muslim community must be mobilized to face the enemy. But when the war is over, each must return to their original duties, except for a number of people who are given special tasks to maintain security and order, in the military and police services.

Because this verse has established that the function of knowledge is to educate the ummah, it cannot be justified if there are Muslims who seek knowledge only to pursue rank and position or personal gain, let alone to use knowledge as pride and arrogance towards groups that have not received knowledge.

People who have knowledge must be beacons and guides for their people. They must spread their knowledge, and guide others to have knowledge as well. In addition, they themselves must also practice their knowledge in order to be an example and role model for those around them in obedience to carrying out religious regulations and teachings.

Thus, it can be understood that in the field of knowledge, every believer has three kinds of obligations, namely: seeking knowledge, practicing it, and teaching it to others.

According to the explicit understanding of this verse, the obligation to seek knowledge that is emphasized in the sight of Allah is in the field of religious knowledge. However, religion is a system of life that encompasses all aspects and facets of human life. Every knowledge that is useful and can educate their lives, and does not conflict with religious norms, must be studied. Muslims are commanded by Allah to prosper this earth and create a good life. While knowledge is a means to achieve that goal. Every means necessary to carry out an obligation is also obligatory. In this case, the Islamic scholars have established a rule that reads:

Sesuatu yang diperlukan untuk melaksanakan yang wajib, maka ia wajib pula hukumnya. (That which is necessary to fulfill an obligation is also obligatory).

Because of the importance of the function of knowledge and scholars, some Islamic countries exempt ulama (scholars) and students at religious colleges from military service, so that teaching and development of knowledge can always run smoothly, unless the country is facing a great danger, which must be faced by all levels of society.
text.123:
The guidance and direction for warfare that Allah shows in this verse to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and the Muslims is to first fight the enemies of Islam who are on the line of the circle closest to the center of the Islamic community's position, and then continue to the circle that is further away.

This is based on the principle that the wars waged by Muslims are only to secure the path of Islamic da'wah and to protect the safety of Muslims, while the da'wah itself also begins with those who are closest, and then continues to those who are further away. Thus, there is harmony between Islamic da'wah and warfare.

This guidance has been well implemented by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), both in the field of da'wah and in warfare, which functions to secure the da'wah. Regarding da'wah, he carried it out first to his closest family and close friends, in accordance with Allah's guidance.

"And warn, (O Muhammad), your closest relatives." (ash-Syu'ara/26: 214)

And His word in another verse:

"...and that you may warn the Mother of Cities (Makkah) and those around it." (al-An'am/6: 92)

Then, he continued this da'wah to the wider community, not only within the Arab region, but also to the kings and nations around the Arabian Peninsula.

Likewise, in terms of warfare, in accordance with the previous verses, it began with the closest enemies of Islam, who were always plotting to hinder the continuation of Islamic da'wah. Then it continued to the Arab tribes that were further away from the center of the position or base of the Muslim community. After the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) died, the caliphs after him continued the war to more distant areas, namely to the lands of Sham (Syria) and Iraq. Then it penetrated into the continent of Africa (to the West) and Persia, Khurasan, even to the Hindukush mountains (to the East) in accordance with the expansion of Islamic da'wah.

The enemies of Islam who were closest to the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims at that time were the disbelievers consisting of the Jews who lived in the city of Medina, then in Khaibar, and then those who fought the Muslims in the Battle of Tabuk, and after that the enemies of Islam in the Sham region, which at that time was under the rule of the Eastern Roman Empire centered in Byzantium.

The war strategy of starting from the closest to the furthest is very appropriate, viewed from various aspects, namely: from the aspect of the possibility of transportation facilities, supplies, and costs. The closer the place, the easier the transportation methods, and thus the smaller the costs and supplies needed. The further the place to be reached, the more difficult the transportation, and the more time and supplies are needed. Naturally, the more costs and energy are needed.

War in the guidance of Islamic teachings is a struggle that must be prepared for the creation of peace, as the saying in Arabic, which is expressed in the sentence:

"Peace that is armed."

In general rules it is usually said, we must always be ready for war to create peace. If we are not in a state of readiness for war, the enemy can attack us at any time, but if we are in a state of readiness for war, the enemy will not dare to attack us.

That is why in the Qur'an, especially Surah at-Taubah, many issues of war and guidance to Muslims are revealed to always be ready for war with various strategies to realize peace.

Allah gives His guidance, so that Muslims are able to use violence and force against the disbelievers who hinder Islamic da'wah, if diplomacy and gentle and friendly treatment are no longer useful for them. Muslims are ordered to be fair, compassionate, and friendly to non-Muslims. But if they continue to disturb the interests of Muslims, especially Islamic da'wah, then Muslims must use strength and power, so that they stop their hostility towards Islam and Muslims. This is also mentioned in Allah's word in another verse:

"O Prophet, strive against the disbelievers and the hypocrites and be harsh upon them." (at-Taubah/9: 73)

Thus, it is clear that Muslims must be ready to use two kinds of attitudes in dealing with disbelievers and hypocrites, namely, first, a flexible, gentle, and friendly diplomatic attitude if they want to be invited to make peace. Disbelievers in this relationship are referred to as *kafir mu'ahidi* or *kafir zimmi*, if they are citizens of our country. Second, firm and if necessary use force, if they do not want to be invited to live side by side peacefully. Disbelievers in such conditions are referred to as *kafir harbi*, so there is no way to deal with them except with force and war.

At the end of this verse, Allah assures those who are pious, that He is always with them. This means that Allah gives a guarantee to those who are pious, namely those who always maintain Allah's laws and provisions, that He will always provide His help and assistance. Allah's provisions that need to be considered in the matter of warfare are that Muslims should not be negligent in preparing everything necessary to achieve victory, namely physical and mental strength. Physical strength includes: soldiers who are healthy and strong, effective weapons, strong defense fortresses, as well as sufficient supplies and equipment. While mental strength includes: sincere intentions, high spirits, strong patience and perseverance, as well as accurate war tactics and strong discipline, and solid unity. This also includes war ethics and high morals, namely not being unjust to women, children, weak elderly people, and not being cruel to those who have surrendered or been captured, as long as they do not endanger the interests of Islam and Muslims. To achieve this victory, strong faith is needed, as well as remembering and trusting in Allah.
text.124:
Among the attitudes of the hypocrites during the time of Prophet Muhammad (saw) was that when verses of the Qur'an were revealed to him and conveyed to them, some of them would ask their friends, both from among the hypocrites themselves and their friends from the Muslims who were weak in faith, who among them had their faith increased by the revelation of this surah. This confirms that the Qur'an is truly from Allah, that Muhammad is truly the messenger of Allah, that each verse of the Qur'an is a miracle for Muhammad, and that the Qur'an is not Muhammad's creation.

If we pay attention to the questions of the hypocrites mentioned in these verses, we feel that the purpose of the question is not to ask about something unknown, but to show what is in their hearts; that is, they do not yet believe in the Messenger of Allah, even though their mouths have acknowledged it. In fact, they want the Muslims who are weak in faith to become like them as well. If there were no disease in the hearts of the hypocrites, they would surely know that true faith, accompanied by submission and servitude to Allah, because they have felt and believed in His power, will certainly increase by hearing and reading the verses of the Qur'an, especially if they hear it directly from the Messenger of Allah (saw) himself.

These characteristics of the hypocrites are explained in His word:

"They [think to] deceive Allah and those who believe, but they deceive not except themselves and perceive [it] not. In their hearts is a disease, so Allah has increased their disease; and for them is a painful punishment because they [habitually] used to lie." (al-Baqarah/2: 9-10)

Regarding the impression of the verses of the Qur'an in the hearts of the believers, it is explained in Allah's word:

"Rather, it is distinct verses [preserved] within the breasts of those who have been given knowledge. And none reject Our verses except the wrongdoers." (al-'Ankabut/29: 49)

The question of the hypocrites is answered by Allah with the expression mentioned at the end of this verse, which means that for those who believe, this surah increases their faith and they feel happy.
text.125: The answers to their questions regarding the Al-Qur'an are explained in this verse. As for those whose hearts are doubtful and the hypocrites, namely those whose hearts are full of disbelief while their mouths profess faith, every verse conveyed to them always creates doubt and hypocrisy in their hearts. This kind of thing always increases its influence on them, so that they eventually die as hypocrites who disbelieve. What they experience will be experienced by those after them, whose hearts are the same as theirs, they will die as disbelievers.
text.126: In this verse, Allah does not justify, but rather condemns, the attitude of the hypocrites who remain defiant, unwilling to repent, and unwilling to learn from the various events they have experienced. Even though they have been brought trials and bitter experiences and defeats every year, which should strengthen a person's faith so that they are able to distinguish between right and wrong. These various trials, tests, and experiences, if they were to reflect on them properly, would certainly lead them to the conclusion that Muhammad is truly the Messenger of Allah sent to them. However, they remain in denial and are unwilling to repent and learn from it. In fact, their hearts become more misguided and more in denial.
text.127:
This verse explains the attitude and actions of the hypocrites in the Prophet's assembly when Quranic verses were revealed. When a verse or surah was revealed to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), they would look at each other and wink as a signal to belittle what had been revealed. This attitude of theirs shows that the influence of disbelief had taken deep root in their souls. They actually did not want to listen to the verses of the Qur'an from the Prophet, and they did not want others to receive guidance from the Qur'an.

Another attitude of the hypocrites was: they would secretly leave the Prophet's assembly (peace and blessings be upon him) while asking each other, "Did anyone see us leaving the assembly?" Meanwhile, the believers listened to and paid attention to the verses with humility and full attention.

It is this attitude of the hypocrites that caused Allah to turn their hearts away from faith and from the guidance contained in the verses of the Qur'an. Allah did that because they had first denied the Prophet's call and ignored the guidance of the Qur'an.
text.128:
Although this verse is specifically addressed to the Arab people during the Prophet's time, it is also intended for all of humanity. It was initially directed to the Arabs of the Prophet's era because the Qur'an was first revealed to them. Since the Qur'an is in Arabic, the Arabs were best able to understand and appreciate its literary excellence. Thus, they could easily convey it to people other than Arabs. If the Arabs themselves did not believe in Muhammad and the Qur'an, it would certainly be more difficult for non-Arabs to believe.

This verse seems to remind the Arabs, as its content states, "O Arabs, a Messenger has been sent from among yourselves, whose origin and personality you fully know, and you know him better than others."

Some commentators (mufassir) interpret the phrase "Rasulun min anfusikum" with the hadith:

The Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "Indeed, Allah has chosen Bani Kinanah from the descendants of Ismail, and chosen the tribe of Quraysh from Bani Kinanah, and chosen Bani Hashim from the tribe of Quraysh, and Allah has chosen me from Bani Hashim." (Narrated by Muslim and at-Tirmidhi from Wasilah bin Asqa)

From the verse and hadith above, it can be understood about the purity of the Prophet Muhammad's lineage, which comes from the chosen tribes of the Arab people. And the Arabs know this very well.

Prophet Muhammad (saw), who comes from a good and honorable lineage, has noble and great qualities, namely:

1. The Prophet feels unhappy if his people are afflicted with something undesirable, such as being humiliated by being colonized and enslaved by the enemies of the Muslims, just as he is also unhappy to see his people afflicted with a painful torment in the Hereafter.

2. The Prophet greatly desires that his people receive guidance from Allah, that their faith increases, and that their condition improves. This desire of his is depicted by Allah in His saying:

If you (Muhammad) are very eager for their guidance, then indeed, Allah does not guide those He leaves astray, and they will have no helpers. (an-Nahl/16: 37)

And Allah says:

And most of the people will not believe, even if you desire it eagerly. (Yusuf/12: 103)

3. The Prophet is always compassionate and very merciful to the Muslims. This desire of his is evident in the purpose of the message he conveyed, which is for people to live happily in this world and the Hereafter.

In this verse, Allah gives two kinds of attributes to Prophet Muhammad, both of which are also attributes of Allah Himself, which are among the "asmaul husna," namely the attribute "rauf" (most compassionate) and the attribute "rahim" (merciful), as mentioned in His saying:

...Indeed, Allah is full of kindness, Most Merciful towards mankind. (al-Baqarah/2: 143)

The bestowal of these two attributes upon Muhammad indicates that Allah made Muhammad a Messenger whom He honored.
text.129:
This verse commands Prophet Muhammad and his followers that if the disbelievers and hypocrites still refuse to believe after guidance has been brought to them, say to them, "Sufficient for me is Allah, and He will help me. There is no god worthy of worship except Him. Only in Him do I put my trust and submit myself, and only He manages and governs the universe. He possesses the Magnificent Throne ('Arsy)."

It is narrated from Zaid bin Thabit, who was assigned by 'Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) to collect the Quran that was still uncollected during the time of Abu Bakr, that Zaid said, "...Until I obtained the last two verses of Surah at-Taubah from the notes of Khuzaimah bin Thabit al-Anshari. I had not obtained them previously from anyone, while these two verses were memorized and known by many people." (Narrated by al-Bukhari, at-Tirmidzi, an-Nasa'i and other narrators).
